title: face mask uk who is exempt
story: From July , people will have to wear face masks in shops and supermarkets - and anyone refusing to do so will be fined up to £.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe government announced that from July  people entering shops will have to wear a face covering. Customers who do not wear one will face a £ fine, but it could be cut to £they pay within a fortnight.Also, it has been compulsory for travellers to wear a mask on public transport since June , .But Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said: There will be exceptions to these rules for very young children, disabled people and those with breathing dficulties.According to the official Government guidance, the following groups are not required to wear a face-covering while using public transport or in a shop:There are also a series of factors which the Government describes as a “reasonable excuse”, which also means you don’t have to wear a mask:Travellers who are not among the exempt categories will be refused boardingthey are not wearing a mask or told to get off.Mr Shapps said: I can announce that as of Monday, June , face coverings will become mandatory on public transport.The evidence suggests that wearing a face masks offers some, limited protection.You can be refused travelyou dont comply and you could be fined.It’s a condition of travel. You cannot travelyou are not wearing a face covering.On July , Matt Hancock confirmed that from July  it would be mandatory for people in England to wear face masks in shops and supermarkets.Shopkeepers have been asked to implement the new rules in their stores.But ultimately, the new rules on wearing masks in shops will be enforced by the police, not shop workers.Anyone spotted flouting the new rules could be hit with a £ fine.Doctors have insisted masks are crucial to slow the spread of coronavirus and make le safer for the most vulnerable.On July , Chair of the British Medical Association’s Medical Academic Staff Committee and Exeter University lecturer Dr David Strain said: “We need masks to slow the spread and make le safer for the most vulnerable to go about essential activities.“Yesterday more than  people tested positive for the virus, which the ONS figures suggest is only about a third of the true number of new cases in the UK.“The remaining two thirds of the population with the virus are the ‘silent spreaders’, people who carry and can potentially spread the virus despite having no symptoms themselves.“The mandatory use of face coverings will reduce the risk to the population at large from these iniduals.”Those who are exempted from wearing a face mask will be asked to get a face-covering exemption card.Those exempt will be required to carry the card on their person while using public transport.The card is available to download for free on the TfL website.TfL will also recognise similar cards that may have been issued by other transport operators. The card can also be displayed on a smartphone.If you do not have a printer or a smartphone, you can contact TfL and they will print and post a card to you. title: carol cooper fatimas inspiring recovery
story: For Fatima spent a remarkably long time on a ventilator and her recovery so far is equally remarkable.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesCovid- is a new infection so experts still don’t know all about it. It has been clear from the start seriously ill patients need the help of a ventilator because they are no longer able to breathe for themselves.The most common method is via a tube down the windpipe attached to the ventilator. But this does present dangers.Within ten days, a tracheostomy is often done through the neck to ease pressure on the windpipe, save vocal cords and reduce the need for sedatives. days in a coma days on ventilation days in intensive care days in hospital so far, from March  to July Apart from the risk also of le-threatening lung infections, long-term ventilating has also been linked with muscle weakness, nerve problems, and nutritional complications.Some half of patients who need a ventilator survive. title: health experts derail britain covid recovery
story: This dubious fad has split health experts, derailed the faltering post-Covid economic recovery and transformed us into faceless paranoid creatures.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesFar from encouraging ato work, pub le and shopping, face masks are stoking fears which have converted sceptical Britain into a nation of hypochondriacs.Instead of social harmony, we are being ided by confusing new masking rituals and instant anonymity. We are all aliens now.Just as herd immunity kicks in, infection risks drop to near-zero and scientists find new ways to keep us out of intensive care, neurotic Britain has gone into hiding.Boris Johnson warns this will continue until November “at the earliest”, with a chance of normality in time for a Christmas shopping spree.Fat chance. Nervous nellies love being scared.If we get any sort of winter flu — even without a second Covid wave and preposterous forecasts of , dead — many will stay indoors until spring  at the earliest.By which time, UK plc will be bankrupt, its economy broken in a thousand pieces.Everyone in authority has no doubt responded with the best of intentions to this shambles, including Public Health England.But come the inevitable public inquiry, this giant qango will find itself in the dock for unforced errors.The latest came last week when chief scientist Patrick Vallance blithely told MPs: “There is absolutely no reason to change advice to stay at home.”Let me to take you by the hand, Sir Patrick, and lead you through the streets of London.This is the fabled Square Mile, the global financial hub which, pre-Covid, generated half a trillion pounds a year —  per cent of the nation’s wealth.The capital usually attracts , visitors a day.Today it’s a ghost town, lucky to get ,.High-rise office blocks are empty. Street level stores, restaurants and coffee shops are locked and barred, some for ever. In pre-Covid times, you were rarely more than a couple of feet from someone in a hurry. Today you could fire a machine gun at rush hour and hit no one.That won’t change by , let alone by Christmas.Take a walk down Fleet Street, Sir Patrick, along the shuttered Strand, past Aldwych and mothballed theatreland.As Ralph McTell’s song goes, you might see an old man in the closed-down market kicking up the paper with his worn out shoes — yesterday’s paper telling yesterday’s news.That will be the London Standard, born in , fighting for its le.The governor of the Bank of England, Andrew Bailey, “shocked” by deserted London, warns of dire economic consequences. They are visible already.The Shard is empty. The lights are on in the Gherkin, the Walkie-Talkie and the Cheesegrater but nobody is home. St Bart’s hospital is empty, its thousands of heart and cancer patients left biting their nails with worry at home.Only the construction sites are busy, building brand new empty office blocks.At mainline stations you see more hi-viz jobsworths ordering passengers to wear masks than there are passengers.Firms want to reopen. But what’s the pointeveryone is too scared — or too idle — to come in. Many with secure jobs and salaries are undoubtedly skiving at everyone ’s expense.Only one in five civil servants, most on above-average salaries and gold-plated pensions, are bothering to come in.Are the rest all working energetically from home We are living in a state of collective hysteria, petried of a one-in-, chance of catching a bug which doctors have learned to make no more lethal than a bad dose of flu.The number of “excess deaths” — above the predictable national average — is now below normal.Yet we are staking the entire economy and the health, prosperity and le chances of our children and grandchildren on avoiding a risk which is less than being struck by lightning.THE BBC’s Andrew Marr deliciously caught China and ­Russia’s top envoys lying through their teeth.Beijing’s ambassador dismissed film of Uighur prisoners in chains and blindfolds as fake before squirmingly promising to “get back to you”. If he survives long enough, that is.Then Russia’s Andrei Kelin, a Michael Gove lookalike, shrugged off the Salisbury poisonings as a “dull” story and denied trying to steal our Covid vaccination formula.We believe you, comrades. But it might be a while before you are let loose on British TV again.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc peter crouch save our summer
story: So distracting you might have missed her ability to ask the killer question.“So, how have you been coping without the football this summer, Peter ”HOW How’d you think, Maya  Like Gemma Collins without the Dunkin’ Donuts’ double down deal, is the combination that first springs to mind.But it possibly underestimates the void at the heart of Peter Crouch: Save Our Summer, a series which must have looked like an easy three-pointer about six months ago.It was Euro  plus “Crouchy”, who is everything a footballer’s not meant to be. Quick-witted, smart, self-deprecating, incredibly likeable and a bit odd-looking. A man who gives hope to fans, both through his career and marriage to Abbey Clancy.Then a double calamity struck. Euro  was cancelled and instead of ­canning the project the BBC pressed on with SOS, shackling it with a hostage-to-fortune title and all sorts of baggage and “other stuff” the show could have done ­without as well.Aside from a garden centre set and enormous table, around which Churchill could’ve signed the Yalta agreement, the baggage came in human form: Crouchy’s former team-mates, The Horne Section studio band, a guest comedian and, of course, Maya, who provided my series highlight when she got dangerously side-tracked by the host’s leisure and tourism qualication.“I don’t want to sound silly or anything,” said Maya, carefully setting her own trap, “But what is a GVNQ ”“It’s a GNVQ.” Obviously.As awkwardly as hosts and guests have all gelled, though, the thing that’s really torpedoed this show has been the other stuff. Those outside broadcasts and studio features that were meant to fill the ­football gap, but didn’t.Two regulars were a chino-clad irritant called Fast Dad, who competed against the host to win football memorabilia for a viewer and “Peter’s Extreme Retirement”, which included all the ideas Alan ­Partridge would’ve thought a bit naff, like water-skiing with Joe Cole.The game not even Crouchy’s GNVQ could help him understand, though, was a VAR-related pun called Very Accurate Rhythm.On Saturday it involved Mo Gilligan playing keepie-uppie to The Horne ­Section’s version of Hit Me Baby One More Time. In previous weeks, however, it was Tinie Tempah and Katherine Ryan having a go at swingball and Jimmy Carr playing Mel C at table tennis.There’s a scoreboard as well, yet no sense of what the hell’s going on here, other than the fact that not a single ­person at the BBC knows how to produce light entertainment.If they did, one of them would have given Peter Crouch the two words of prime-time advice he desperately needed to hear. Don’t. Swear.They didn’t, though. Crouchy and his mates swore like he was presenting a late-night E show and so ended up with an E-sized audience of about one ­million. That’s the reason you never see masters of the light entertainment art, Ant  Dec, dropping the F-bomb.In its youth-driven madness, the BBC might think this is a good thing but it alienates the people who actually pay their wages and has direct consequences for Crouch who, before this started, I thought, could have become a ­Saturday night staple. Now  Mystery guest round on A Question Of Sport, tops. That’s how he’s been coping without the football, Maya.And ex-Celtic manager John Barnes enlivening ITV’s Stephen Lawrence: Has Britain Changed  debate by telling the audience it needed to “elevate people like me and people like Barack Obama”, asthe former US President had ever worked with anyone of the magnitude of Jackie McNamara and Regi Blinker.You’re far too modest, John.Celebrity Snoop Dogs, Kevin McCloud: “It’s the much-loved Martine McCutcheon.” The One Show, Amol Rajan: “Today’s first guest is a man of many talents, Nick Knowles.”Peter Crouch: Save Our Summer, Maya Jama to the host: “God loves a trier.”Loves  He’s sent down a plague of locusts for less than SOS.ANYONE who watched last night’s episode of the landmark BBC series Once Upon A Time In Iraq is unlikely to forget it in a hurry.The story of the  invasion is grimly familiar, but what sets this show apart are the testimonies from its eyewitnesses.None of them wastes words. All of them are mesmerising.Two, though, still managed to stand out from the others.The first was a darkly funny Iraqi called Waleed Nesy who, before he became a journalist’s translator, was pro-war and fronted Baghdad’s only state-approved heavy metal band which, I’m desperately hoping, were called Black Sabba’ath.The other was ferociously bright US army officer Lieutenant-Colonel Nate Sassaman, “a charismatic leader of men” who was hoping to bring peace, democracy and lots of other empty promises to the country until he entered his first local medical centre and: “I’m telling you, the woman running it  She was as hard as a woodpecker’s lips.”Both were damaged by the catastrophe that unfolded and, in the case of Sassaman, helped cause, but they somehow retained their humanity, honesty and sense of humour, which made their testimony all the more astonishing.Like all great war documentaries, Once Upon A Time In Iraq was also prepared to let silence tell the story when the brutality or stupidity became too overwhelming.They made an exception for Waleed, though, when, six weeks into the invasion, President George W Bush boldly declared: “Mission accomplished.”“Mission accomplished  Oh yeah  . . . SERIOUSLY ”Three more episodes will tell you very graphically how well that worked out and they’re as good as anything you’ve watched all year.INCIDENTALLY, I’m grateful to This Morning hosts Ruth Langsford and Eamonn Holmes for revealing blind Celebrity MasterChef contestant Amar Lat measured liquids with “talking jugs”.Which, by a million-to-one coincidence, was also ITV’s original working title for Loose Women.My Strange Addiction: “Eating mattresses can lead to liver damage, intestinal blockage and even death.”But on the plus side, it won’t leave you bed-ridden.Emile Heskey: “When your back’s against the wall, it’s easy to lie down.”Jeff Stelling: “This game will be over when the referee blows the final whistle.”And Chris Kamara: “Three points is another point on the board.”BY the way,you haven’t ever seen Chernobyl, one of the greatest TV dramas ever made, Friday, pm, Sky Atlantic, is your chance.No further excuses will be accepted.WITH no little air of self-congratulation, last week, Celebrity MasterChef welcomed its first ever blind contestant, “travel presenter” Amar Lat, who arrived with a helper and his own super power.“I’ve started to hear the food talking to me,” he explained. “It’s almost like it’s communicating to me and it’s saying . . .”“Don’t worry, Amar. The BBC won’t chuck you out first. It’d look bad.”As good fortune would have it, he didn’t need to worry too much as it was the worst line-up of the series and included Gethin Jones, playing to the camera, rapper Lady Leshurr, whose speciality seemed to be “in-flight meals” and Alan Partridge star Felicity “Lynn Benfield” Montagu, who served up a salad for the guest judges that looked like a Haitian voodoo rattle.The real fall guy, though, appeared to be Jeff Brazier who, at the first challenge, was tugging away at a string of garlic for a good ten seconds before he twigged. “Ah. It’s a decoration. It’s made of polystyrene.”Those people who cry at absolutely everything, of course, were quick to let everyone  know Amar’s eventual progression to the semi-final made them “cry”.I thought the highlight of the week, however, came at the end of the pair’s dessert challenge when the judges’ comments led Amar to ask: “Are you two fat ” and Gregg Wallace replied: “Are you familiar with Jean-Claude Van Damme ”“Yes.”Then get someone to talk you through his voiceover on Minions: The Rise Of Gru.The resemblance is uncanny.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: douglas murray world wakes up china menace
story: In the s it was the nuclear catastrophe at Chernobyl that revealed to the world the truth about Soviet communism.Not that it was cruel — the world knew that.Not that it was a dictatorship — the world knew that, too.What the Chernobyl meltdown showed was that the cruel Soviet dictatorship was also inept.So it is in recent months with China and the virus that came from the city of Wuhan.The world already knew all it needed to know about China and the Communist Party which runs that country.We knew it was a one-party dictatorship. We knew it cracked down on all domestic opposition. We knew of the way in which they were undercutting the economies of the West.But not until the spread of the Wuhan virus did so many people come to realise how untrustworthy the Chinese leadership is.Now, every day brings more bad news about China. It isn’t because China is doing any-thing new. It is because China has caught the world’s attention.Not in a good way.Just consider the events of recent days.The Chinese government’s mistreatment of its Uighur population in the province of Xinjiang has been known about for years.The Muslim minority group, who regard themselves as closer to Central Asian countries — their language is related to Turkish — have long been in the government’s sights.Armed guardsFor years the Chinese Communist Party has had Xinjiang under its version of special measures.Claiming the one-time independent state, which borders eight countries, constitutes a special security risk, the communists have had the people there under mass surveillance.Even before the recent mass imprisonment, they have had them subjected to forced labour.In recent years they have subjected the entire population to compulsory birth control to try to reduce the size of the population.But for years the world’s attention was not focused on this.We all had troubles of our own to look to.So the Chinese authorities got away with putting perhaps as many as one million Uighur people in what are basically concentration camps — places where these people are meant to be “re-educated” and otherwise “corrected”.Now, drone footage has surfaced which shows shackled, blindfolded prisoners in the province being marched on to trains by rows of armed guards.The scenes are awful.As our Foreign Secretary, Dominic Raab, rightly said at the weekend, they are “reminiscent of something we have not seen for a very long time”.He is right.Yet when the Chinese Ambassador to our country was asked about this at the weekend, he pretended to have no idea what the footage was.He even tried to ert attention by asking his inter- viewer whether he had ever himself been to the charming province in question.But we are not as easily distracted by China as we used to be. Every day brings fresh causes.First, we had China’s appalling behaviour in Hong Kong, breaking its agreements with the UK and cracking down on the local population.Then last week came our Government’s decision to remove Chinese firm Huawei from any involvement in Britain’s G network.Huawei is basically a Chinese government agency and it would have been a serious security breach to allow it to control all our internet communications. Or to develop a back door for looking into them.Then a number of senior Conservatives warned that social media app TikTok is “as much of a threat” to Britain as Huawei.That may sound funny to parents whose children are addicted to it.For most of us, the app is just a source of amusement or bemusement.Depending on your age.But whatever your reaction to it, a growing number of people believe Chinese tech-nologies like TikTok are not safe. Because TikTok’s parent company is ByteDance, a Chinese firm founded in .Of course, the company claims to be independent, as all such firms do, but in China major firms are not independent as they are in Britain or other free societies.Critics insist TikTok could easily be used by hostile forces to harvest information from, and otherwise target, all those who use it.Of course, all of this has brought a degree of sabre-rattling from Beijing.China’s leaders have got used to telling everyone  what to do.As they spread their financial wings in recent decades, countries like ours were very keen to enjoy the benefits.Universities in the UK repeatedly took money from China. Money with strings attached.But money that some of our greedier universities thought was free. Only later learning otherwise.Naturally, the turnaround of recent months has been badly received in Beijing.Its ambassadors and state media have spent recent days pretending it is Britain that is the untrustworthy partner.They are wrong.We are not inconsistent or unfair. We are simply a country that has begun to wake up to a threat.Like the rest of the world. And not a moment too soon.Jaguar Land Rover builds cars for them under a joint venture with Chery Automobile. Pharmaceutical giant AstraZeneca has , employees in China across several manufacturing sites, as well as an innovation centre and a ­campus.So as tensions ramp up after the decision to remove Huawei from the UK’s G network, Britain should remember it, too, has aces to play. Most notably tech and skills.To learn about these is why so many Chinese students come to our universities. It is the same reason why state-owned China General Nuclear Power is a one-third partner in the new nuclear power station at Hinkley Point C in Somerset.It will have a front-row seat to the latest tech as China prepares to build around  reactors of its own.Saying no to Chinese firms is not to be taken lightly.There are around , Chinese companies that do business in the UK. The largest  employ , people.But let’s not forget they need us too.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britains coronavirus vaccine progress global leaders
story: Normally, it takes ten years to develop a vaccine from start to finish, to the point where you can give it widespread to patients.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesAnd you can see with the Oxford announcement just how fast were moving on this. It doesnt mean that were going to ultimately be successful. Right now the range of possibilities is from very early success through to we never get a vaccine against COVID-. What weve got with the Oxford result is clear proof that that vaccine produces a really good immune response in humans. It is very encouraging indeed. Im now cautiously optimistic that this vaccine may work. Were taking those financial risks to run the programmes as fast as we can. Weve already managed to secure  million doses of future supply of the Oxford vaccine.My best estimates are thatthis continues to run with the success that we have had so far, it would not be unreasonable to think that we will be getting some doses of that vaccine this side of Christmas. The UK has also signed deals for options on two other vaccines. When you get to the point where youve got a vaccine concept thats reasonable, then the success rate is typically about ten per cent. And what that tells you is that, to be sure that youre going to get a vaccine, you need multiple shots on goal. You’ve got to back more than one horse, and the UK Government is doing that. We are expecting to host five or six big vaccine trials in the UK in the autumn and yesterday we launched a website to allow the public to register their interest to take part in the trial. We are hoping to have , people per trial, so up to , participants. We’re not looking just for -year-olds, but people from a range of backgrounds and comorbidities. Im a glass half full man. Im cautiously optimistic that by late spring next year there will be several vaccines that will have made it. My confidence is increasing week by week with the news that comes through.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: russia report brexit
story: A bombshell report today revealed Putin sees Britain as a top target and the UK governmentunderestimated the threat of Russia.The long-awaited report by Parliament’s Intelligence and Security Committee confirmed a series of attempts by the Kremlin to interfere in British democracy.The -page document analysed Russian meddling in UK elections and referendums across donations, cyber attacks and even assassinations.The shocking document says: “It is clear that Russia currently poses a signicant threat to the UK on a number of fronts – from espionage to interference in democratic processes, and to serious crime.The UK is one of Russia’s top Western intelligence targets: particularly given the UK’s firm stance against recent Russian aggression and the UK-led international response to the  Salisbury attack. Russia’s intelligence services are disproportionately large and powerful and, given the lack of rule of law, are able to act without constraint.It also warned Britain had been playing catch-up to the threat posed by the Kremlin, with Russian interference the new normal.But the Prime Ministers Official Spokesman said Mr Johnson is absolutely confident the Brexit result was fair.  The results of the  month long investigation were finally published this morning after a nine month delay.The report said: The report found no evidence of interference in the Brexit vote.It warned it was “impossible to assess” any level of involvement from Russia and instead demanded a further probe.Committee member Stewart Hosie MP said: The report reveals that no one in government knewRussia interfered in or sought to influence the [Brexit] referendum because they did not want to know.The UK Government have actively avoided looking for evidence that Russia interfered, we were told they hadnt seen any evidence but that is meaninglessthey didnt even look for it.Kevan Jones MP added: We wanted to see the post-referendum assessments but there isnt one there has been no assessment of Russian interference in the EU referendum and that goes back to no one wanting to touch this issue with a ft pole.The report also backed Britains voting system to stand up to any attacks.It adds: While the mechanics of our paper-based voting system are largely sound, we cannot be complacent about a hostile state taking deliberate action with the aim of influencing our democratic processes.The committee explained it had sent a request for written evidence from MI on interference and got a reply with just six lines of text.The ISC said it believed this was because the intelligence and security agencies were worried they could be seen to have any role in the UKs democratic processes.It explained: We understand the nervousness around any suggestion that the intelligence Agencies might be involved in the mechanics of the democratic process, but that does not apply when it comes to the protection of those processes.Democracy is intrinsic to our country’s success and well-being. Protecting it must be a ministerial priority, with the Office for Security and Counter-Terrorism taking the policy lead and the operational role sitting with MI.Responding to the report, the Government insisted a retrospective assessment of the EU referendum was not necessary.The Prime Ministers Official Spokesman today insisted Boris Johnson is absolutely confident the  EU referendum result was fair.He added: We havent seen any evidence of successful interference in EU referendum.It suggested interference did take place in the Scottish Independence referendum, labelling the claims Russia was involved as credible.It pointed to the use of bots and trolls as evidence Moscow tried to interfere.Mr Jones said there was clear evidence of Russian interference not just from the Scottish referendum but also the hacking of the Democrats in the US.He added that despite this the Government still failed to direct intelligence agencies to look into any influence in past or future elections.After last weeks revelations Russia had intervened in the  election by amplying documents used by Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, the Intelligence Committee said its future task would be to look at into how widespread the interference was.The report also demanded new legislation to crack down on foreign spies, and accused the Government of being slow to act.It said: “It has been clear for some time that Russia under Putin has moved from potential partner to established threat, fundamentally unwilling to adhere to international law – the murder of Alexander Litvinenko in  and the annexation of Crimea in  were stark indicators of this. We therefore question whether the Government took its eye off the ball because of its focus on counter-terrorism: it was the opinion of the Committee that until recently the Government had badly underestimated the response required to the Russian threat –and is still playing catch up.The committee also raised concerns about which Government organisation is actually responsible for protecting the UK against foreign interference.  It said: The defence of those democratic processes has appeared something of a hot potato, with no one organisation considering itself to be in the lead, or apparently willing to conduct an assessment of such interference.The ISC also warned Britain could not stand up to Russia alone.They said: We need other countries to step up with the UK and attach a cost to Putin’s actions. Salisbury must not be allowed to become the high water mark in international unity over the Russia threat.Speaking after the publication of the report, the Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab dismissed claims Britain had not handled Russia properly. He said: “Russia is a top security priority. We call out Russia when its necessary.“We’ve shown that in relation to the cyberattacks on research and development facilities in the US, UK and Canada.“Weve done that together with our partners, and we are not for a second complacent about the threat Russia poses when it comes to cyber.”It blasted “successive governments” for having welcomed Russian oligarchs and their money “with open arms”.The report warned this gave them power and access to influential figures.It said: Successive Governments have welcomed the oligarchs and their money with open arms, providing them with a means of recycling illicit finance through the London laundromat, and connections at the highest levels with access to UK companies and political figures.This has led to a growth industry of enablers including lawyers, accountants, and estate agents who are – wittingly or unwittingly – de facto agents of the Russian state.The report admitted that is now too late to shut the stable door but that the UK can still introduce greater powers and transparency.The report also pointed to a series of  stories pumped out by Russian state broadcasters, as well as through bots online.It has now called for a social media crackdown on fake news.It said: “The Government must now seek to establish a protocol with the social media companies to ensure that they take covert hostile state use of their s seriously, and have clear timescales within which they commit to removing such material.Chief EU Brexit negotiator Guy Verhofstadt claimed the report shows just how many questions remain unanswered about the referendum. Nigel Farage insisted it showed no evidence of Russian involvement, despite the report explaining it did not look for it.Today a Russian Foreign Ministry spokesperson dismissed the report.Mariya Zakharova said: “There was no sensation. It’s Russophobia set in a fake shape”.Russia has been accused of repeated interventions and attacks on British soil.This includes the Salisbury poisoning attack on spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia, .The ex-KGB spy and his daughter Yulia, , were exposed to a nerve agent and fell gravely ill after having a pizza lunch in Salisbury on Sunday, March , .Russia denied that their special services were involved in the attack, which sparked a diplomatic spat and the expulsion of embassy staff.The former head of MI had previously claimed there was no evidence of Russian intervention in the Brexit vote, but that it interfered in the US election.Publication of the report was delayed by Boris Johnson’s decision to call a general election and the need to re-establish the ISC. The PM is likely to discuss Russia in todays meeting with US Secretary of State Michael Pompeo.It comes just days after Putin’s Russia was accused of trying to steal a coronavirus vaccine from Britain.The Kremlin laughed off the allegations calling them “foggy and contradictory”.Security sources say the high-tech espionage was ordered “at the highest levels” - possibly by Putin himself.One source told The Sun the Kremlin was “terried of being left behind” in the new Cold War race to find a vaccine.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: red rash mouth new coronavirus symptom
story: The new research suggests that Covid patients could develop a rash just  days after showing other key coronavirus symptoms such as a new persistent cough.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesExperts in Spain examined the mouths of  coronavirus patients who had rashes on their skin to seethey had enanthemor a rash inside the body on the mucous membrane.The mucous membrane lines many tracts in the body and is found in the mouth, nose, eyelids and lungs.Coronavirus patients at Roman y Cajal University Hospital in Madrid, Spain were given dermatology appointments title: toddler covered in scratches aldi cot mattress
story: Lucy Morrison, , claims rusty exposed springs were to blame for red marks on little Finleys body.She only discovered the metal sticking out of the mattress when stripping its sheets to be cleaned.The young mum now fears that hundreds of babies across the country are at risk of serious injury.Lucy, from Dagenham, East London, rushed to her local Aldi branch demanding a full £ refund.She told The Sun: “I went to strip the mattress protector to wash it and saw springs exposed.“For a while my son had scratches on his face and his feet - at first I thought that it was his nails.“He didn’t receive any serious injuries - thank god.“When I took it to the store they didn’t take it seriously at all. title: pompeo boris china huawei
story: The US Secretary of State said there needed to be a global coalition of countries to keep Chinas power in check after a meeting with the PM and Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab today.The Secretary of State said he supported the UKs decision to refuse to extradite to Hong Kong after China imposed tough new national security laws on Hong Kongers - following similar decisions from the US, Canada and Australia. Mr Raab also announced yesterday the UK would cease doing any arms deals with Hong Kng because of the power China holds over it.In a joint statement Mr Pompeo said he wanted to use the meeting as an opportunity to praise the British Government for its principled response.Mr Raab said the pair discussed how the UK and US need to work together to make sure the global telecoms industry is more erse after the Government decided to ban Huawei from Britains G network. Mr Pompeo said keeping Chinese state-owned Huawei out was essential to keep citizens private data safe. Mr Pompeo urged the UK to join the US in making every effort to push back against Chinese aggression.After a meeting with Boris Johnson and Dominic Raab, Mr Pompeo said today: We want every nation to push back against the Chinese Communist Partysefforts in every dimension. In a tirade against China, Mr Pompeo said: You cant threaten countries and bully them in the Himalayas, you cant engage in cover ups and co-op international institutions like the World Health Organisation.We want to see every nation who understands freedom and democracy and values that and knows that its important to their own people, their own sovereign country, to be successful, to understand this threat the Chinese Communist Partyis posing.And to work both themselves and collectively to restore what is rightfully ours.He accused China ofstealing American intellectual property and reminded people that coronavirus originated in China. He added: We want every country to work against that kind of activity. Its not about language, its not about words. We hope we can build out a coalition that understands this and work collectively to convince the CCP its not in their best interests to engage in this kind of behaviour.Mr Pompeos anti-China speech struck a very dferent note to the PMs insistence yesterday he would not be pushed into a knee-jerk Sinophobe reaction on everything to do with China. What we wont do is completely abandon our relationship with China, China is going to be a giant factor in our geopolitics, weve got to have a calibrated response, Mr Johnson said yesterday. Were going to be tough on some things but also continue to engageon others. A spokesperson for the PM said earlier today: They spoke about shared global security and foreign policy issues, including China’s actions in Hong Kong and Xinjiang, the situation in Iran and the Middle East Peace Process.The U-turn decision to scrap Huawei came after heavy pressure from Mr Pompeo earlier this year to deny the Chinese state-owned telecoms giant access to Britains networks. Mr Pompeo said this afternoon he had had a constructive visit with the PM. He said: Our two countries long-standing, strong bilateral relationship has laid the foundation for todays candid discussion on issues ranging from G telecommunication to our negotiations for a U.S. - UK free trade agreement. In a statement to the House of Commons on UK-China relations, Mr Raab said yesterday: Given the role China has now assumed for the internal security of Hong Kong, and the authority it is exerting over law enforcement, the UK will extend the arms embargo we have applied to mainland China.The Government has decided to suspend the extradition treaty immediately and indefinitely.We will not consider reactivating those measures unless there are clear and robust safeguards which are able to prevent extradition from the UK being misused under the new national security legislation.I will just say this the UK is watching and the whole world is watching.Mr Johnsons spokesman said the US and the UK were still working towards a trade deal as negotiations with Brexit continued to stall.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uni lecturer sacked jewish cleverest germans engineers
story: Stephen Lamonby claimed his comments were not racist or offensive because he was using positive stereotypes.The -year-old also said he had a soft spot for young black men because they are underprivileged and need all the help they can get.An employment tribunal this week heard he made the remarks during a meeting with Dr Janet Bonar, his course leader at Solent University in Southampton, Hampshire.The pair had been having a conversation in the canteen at the university in March  when Mr Lamonby, an engineer, made a series of comments.He said that in his experience people, from dferent countries had become good at certain things due to high exposure.And Mr Lamonby, who had worked at Solent as a part-time associate lecturer for six years, claimed that Germans are good at engineering because they are exposed to a high level of industry from an early stage in their lives.He also said: I have a soft spot for young black males. I do think that they are underprivileged and many [are] without fathers [and] need all the help they can get.During their discussion, Dr Bonar, an engineering lecturer, mentioned she had a degree in physics and Lamonby reacted by saying Jewish people had a particular gt for the subject.He used Einstein as an example, before asking Dr Bonarshe was Jewish.The lecturer took offence to this and shouted that Mr Lamonby was a racist.In response, he said: I believe that the Jewish are the cleverest people in the world. They are much maligned because of it.I askedyou were Jewish because of your ability with maths [and] physics, which is a speciality of theirs.A few hours later, Dr Bonar emailed Mr Lamonby to say that in the future, she hoped conversations they had would be focused on their studies, rather than their widely dferent views on race and national characteristics,But he replied to say he wasnt used to being smacked down like a schoolboy and called a racist.After an investigation was launched, Mr Lamonby defended his comments again and gave another example of high exposure - of Eskimos being good at fishing.He claimed he was shocked by Dr Bonars reaction and said: My comments were simply stating that, arising from my letime of experience, I have come to believe that certain nationalities have developed a higher level of skill in some areas.This is directly related to the level of exposure to criteria such as industry and education. This is not radical thinking it is simply a view that reflects environmental privilege in general terms.During a final disciplinary hearing he eventually admitted he had been clumsy in his language and apologised profoundly.He said he had no intention of being racist.Despite this, he continued to make inappropriate comments during the hearing, referring to ethnic groups as ‘they’ and to Jews having neurological dferences.Vice Chancellor Julie Hall, who chaired the hearing, said Mr Lamonby did not understand that what he had said was offensive. He was dismissed for gross misconduct following the tribunal, which was held in Bristol.Officials at the hearing concluded that the university had a duty to its multi-cultural, predominantly young student body to protect them from potential acts of racism, and dismissed his claims of unfair dismissal and breach of contract.A judge said: For the avoidance of doubt, I find that it is clearly at least potentially racist to group nationalities, races, ethnic or religious groups, by entire categories and to ascribe certain abilities or talents - or the opposite -to them.Following the ruling, Mr Lamonby said he would be appealing, claiming he was a victim of a woke culture and that universities are totally obsessed with racism.I think the judgement came down to the fact the judge was a woke judge, he said.You cant make any comments [in universities] now because they are totally obsessed with racism and to talk about Jews in the context of racism is crazy because they are not even a race, they are an ethnicity.Free speech is totally dead in universities.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: teachers pay rise turned up school
story: Boris Johnson handed pay rises to more than , public sector workers across seven dferent workforces today - including police, soldiers, teachers and prison guards.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesSchool teachers and doctors were awarded the biggest pay bump in recognition of their efforts on the frontline battle against coronavirus.Teachers will get the highest rise of . per cent - meaning a school worker on £, will receive nearly an extra £, a year.It has prompted an angry response from some parents, with one writing on Twitter: Dont agree about the teachers! officers will receive a . per cent rise.Judges and senior civil servants will see a  per cent increase.It is the third above-inflation pay rise for the majority of public sector workers following seven years of austerity that saw salary increases capped at  per cent.More than a million NHS workers have already been given a pay rise of about  per cent this year under their three-year Agenda for by those in the public sector in responding to the unprecedented challenges for the country during the Covid- outbreak.The Treasury said the money will come from existing departmental budgets.Announcing the pay rises last night, Mr Sunak said: “These past months have underlined what we always knew – that our public sector workers make a vital contribution to our country and that we can rely on them when we need them.“It’s right therefore that we follow the recommendations of the independent pay bodies with this set of real-terms pay rises.”However, the government was criticised by national trade union TUC for not making up a decade of real-terms pay cuts for frontline workers.The Conservatives previously enforced a  per cent pay rise cap on public sector workers, but this was scrapped after seven years by then-party leader Theresa May in .TUC general secretary Frances OGrady also called for social care workers to join the ranks of those being offered a pay rise.She title: alzheimers preventable 10 signs weight gain stress
story: Weight gain and stress may be key factors but swt action to tackle them could stop dementia later in le, according to new research.The study, published in the Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery and Psychiatry revealed the ten signs you need to watch out for.Cognitive activity, high body mass index in late le, depression, diabetes, and high blood pressure were all on the list - as was head trauma.As well as these, researchers said a good education in early le was also key as is getting enough sleep, correct levels of vitamin C and regular physical activity.Around , people in the UK currently have dementia, with two thirds having Alzheimer’s.The condition is a leading cause of death and there have been no new drug treatments for the condition in  years.Indeed, it is the most common trigger for dementia.Alzheimers disease is named after the doctor who first described it in medical literature, Alois Alzheimer.A hallmark of the disease is the build-up of amyloid beta proteins in the brain, to cause plaques.This results in the loss of connections between nerve cells in the brain, and ultimately the death of those cells and a loss of brain tissue.Those people living with Alzheimers also have a shortage of some key chemicals in the brain, which help transmit messages.A lack of these chemicals means the brain is unable to process some messages as it would previously.Researchers led by Professor Jin-Tai Yu at Fudan University in China reviewed and analysed  studies.They found  proposed suggestions that could be used to try and prevent the illness.There were “Class ” suggestions within these which made it into the ten to watch out for.Nearly two thirds involved risk factors such as blood pressure and cholesterol levels - adding further evidence which shows that keeping healthy can help prevent the illness.Two interventions found in the study were not recommended and these included oestrogen replacement therapy and use of acetylcholinesterase inhibitors .The researchers said this was the largest and most comprehensive study for Alzheimer’s to date.They concluded: This study provides an advanced and contemporary survey of the evidence, suggesting that more high-quality observational prospective studies and randomised controlled trials are urgently needed to strengthen the evidence base for uncovering more promising approaches to preventing Alzheimers disease.Fiona Carragher, director of research and influencing at the Alzheimers Society, said: In recent years, research has suggested that nearly a third of dementia cases may be preventable.This review builds on this idea, specically in relation to Alzheimers disease and how certain risk factors, many of which are associated with cardiovascular health, may be within our control.She highlighted that a deeper e in needed to understand the risk factors.This review demonstrates that, while observational studies are useful to help identy potential risk factors, we need to see many more interventional trials to understand what the best approaches are to preventing Alzheimers disease developing in the first place.We dont have all the answers yet, but we do know that small steps to improving your physical and mental health can make a big dference, like walking to your local shop for milk instead of jumping in the car.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: small businesses rishi sunak call timeout on firms rent
story: Over nearly two decades he has handed his landlord almost £million in rent — and never missed a payment.But when lockdown forced him to shut the doors of the Milk  Honey bar in Soho, central London, Jonathan’s landlord insisted on the rent being paid IN FULL.Now the bar has reopened and is struggling, the landlord has refused to negotiate a lower rate.It has led to Jonathan, , launching the National Time Out campaign, calling on Chancellor Rishi Sunak to give tenants of commercial premises a ONE-YEAR break from paying rent. He says: “I am not getting one day free from the landlord, nothing.“Milk  Honey is just one of hundreds of thousands of small businesses this is happening to.”With no income because of lockdown, only around a third of business tenants managed to meet their quarterly rent payments in June. Jonathan, who also runs four food markets, pays a total of £.million a year to landlords.Only one has offered a reduction — writing off £,, the equivalent of six months.Jonathan’s scheme has been backed by more than , pubs, bars, clubs and restaurants.It is a plan, he says, that will not cost the taxpayer a penny and will save around two million jobs.Here is how National Time Out would work:Jonathan says: “Landlords need to step in and support their tenants.“But surveys show that  per cent of landlords of hospitality premises were still expecting full payment. That is just not realistic.“Landlords need a debt repayment break, too. “Almost all of them borrow money against their buildings, andthey are giving tenants a rent break, we need to give them a debt repayment break.”His campaign group, which includes UK Burger King boss Alasdair Murdoch, celebrity chefs and thousands of owners of small businesses, has had previous success in getting the Chancellor to change the law.In March they persuaded Mr Sunak to ban landlords from evicting tenants during the coronavirus crisis.It was originally for three months but has been extended until the end of September. Jonathan says: “The Government made legislation in days from me suggesting it. “By moving quickly they gave everyone breathing space, which was fantastic.“I think the Government hoped landlords would see sense, help their tenants out and deals would get done.“But that has not happened. We need Government to push landlords to the negotiating table.“It is about tenants, landlords and bankers all sharing the pain.“It cannot all be forced on to the tenants.”Jonathan fears thata National Time Out scheme does not come, there will be a “rents Armageddon”.He says: “On October , all the landlords that are sharks and vultures will be circling around premises ready to change the locks.“If Rishi does not do something about Britain’s rent debt then  per cent of hospitality businesses will not be open and that will mean the loss of two million jobs.”The Milk  Honey landlords were unavailable for comment.PUBLICAN Debbie Lloyd owes her landlords more than £, for the  weeks of lockdown. Her Masons Arms pub in Kemberton, Shrops, is too small to reopen while social distancing rules are in place so she is still not bringing in any money.Debbie, , says: “The landlords said we would still have to pay in full and we’d have  weeks to pay back the rent arrears. They did say thatwe opened on July  they might offer us some discount.“But it’s not worth reopening the doors when I have to find rent plus arrears with only  per cent income. “It’s impossible and they have offered us no help whatsoever. So I have given them a month’s notice and stripped everything out that I paid for. But I will still owe them the rent.“I think the National Time Out campaign is a fantastic idea that would help people like me. I really hope the Government listens.”Debbie’s landlords were not available for comment.PHILIP Carter runs a sandwich shop in Catterick Garrison, in the North Yorks constituency of Chancellor Rishi Sunak.The -year-old says: “We are negotiating with the landlord to see what deal we can cut. “Some landlords have been really good and helpful while others just say a blanket ‘no’.“Tenants near us have said their landlords are not being helpful. “Businesses like ours have been closed for at least four months and we have come back to a very reduced trade. “The campaign to give tenants like us a break would help thousands.”HAIRDRESSER Dennise Smith used some of her £, coronavirus council grant to pay her rent during lockdown.Although her salon in Croydon, South London, has reopened, Dennise, , fears she may struggle to pay her £,-a-month rent as trade is so uncertain.She says: “I haven’t missed one payment in five years. We have reopened but there are so many restrictions you cannot be as busy.“I don’t think I’m going to be taking anything like the same money as I did before Covid.“Anything that could help to reduce the rent while we get up on our feet would be a boost.” As head of the National Time Out campaign Jonathan Downey explains, hundreds of small businesses are closing their doors for the last time just as punters cautiously start to .Why  Because despite being forbidden from making money during lockdown, publicans and bar owners are now expected to cough up their rental payments — ­in full — to their landlords. We know there’s no quick fix. And Chancellor Rishi Sunak has already been incredibly generous to the hospitality industry. But pub, restaurant and cafe owners are the beating heart of this country. They provide work for thousands and keep millions more cheerful. If they put their heads together, surely banks, landlords and the Government can find a way to give these powerhouse employers a break while they get back on their feet. GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: russia targeted uk campaign political meddling
story: Successive British governments “took their eye off the ball” and “badly underestimated” the threat posed by Moscow, MPs found.London has scornfully become known as “Londongrad” because so many of President Vladimir Putin’s cronies live there.The capital has even become a “laundromat” for dirty Russian money, the report found.And dodgy oligarchs have penetrated the very heart of our democracy by donating to political parties and hiring peers for their businesses.The shocking reach of the Kremlin into the UK was laid bare yesterday in the long-awaited Russia Report by Parliament’s Intelligence and Security Committee.The dossier states: “It is clear Russia poses a signicant threat to the UK on a number of fronts — from espionage to interference in democratic processes, and to serious crime.”Human rights campaigner Bill Browder claimed Mr Putin’s Russia poses a “bigger risk” than it did under Communism.He said: “In a certain way, it is more of a threat than Cold War Russia. A few decades ago, we had our defences up, but now we have relaxed defences and they have fully infiltrated Britain.”The report revealed that there is “credible” evidence Russia tried to interfere in the  Scottish independence referendum to break up the UK.It states that Russian spies tried to hack the Foreign Office and Britain’s top secret lab at Porton Down, Wilts, in the wake of the Salisbury poisoning in  of the former spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter.And the Government is criticised for not investigating claims Russia tried to tamper with the  Brexit vote — with the report calling for an inquiry.Social media giants are blasted for “failing” to stop hostile states, such as Russia, from using their s to target the West.And the dossier claims the Official Secrets Act is out of date and it is not illegal to be a foreign spy in Britain.The damning -page report paints a shocking picture of the sheer scale of Moscow’s interference in Britain’s affairs.It reveals oligarchs exploited a visa scheme set up in , designed to attract investors to the UK, to live in the capital.A growing army of wealthy Russians used London to launder their dirty money.The report states: “What is now clear is that it [the visa] was in fact counter-productive, in that it offered ideal mechanisms by which illicit finance could be recycled through what is referred to as the London ‘laundromat’.”Russian billionaires pumped their dodgy cash into supporting charities, galleries and political parties, the report found.They have used their phenomenal wealth to set up in business in Britain and send their children to expensive private schools.The super-rich Russians also donate to Britain’s political parties, hobnob with MPs and peers and patronise museums.The Intelligence and Security Committee report states: “A number of Members of the House of Lords have business interests linked to Russia. These should be scrutinised.”The committee also said peers should have to declare all earnings over £, as MPs do.The members’ register shows crossbencher Lord Skidelsky is a non-executive director of Russian oil refining company Russneft.Tory Lord Fairfax of Cameron is a director of Sovcomflot UK while Labour’s Lord Ponsonby of Shulbrede is a director of oil and gas firm RNG Joint Stock Company.They were helped in their “nefarious” scheme by an army of “enablers” — UK lawyers, accountants and PR execs who have cashed in on the Russian boom.The report added: “Russian influence in the UK is ‘the new normal’ and there are a lot of Russians with very close links to Mr Putin who are well integrated into the UK business and social scene, and accepted because of their wealth.”Naive ministers in successive governments “took their eye off the ball” when it came to Russia and underestimated the threat the UK was under, the dossier found.Crucial resources were erted from protecting Britain from Russia to focus on terrorism.SNP MP Stewart Hosie, a member of the committee, said the UK was “one of Russia’s top Western intelligence targets”.He added: “Russia poses an all-encompassing security threat which is fuelled by paranoia about the West and a desire to be seen as a resurgent great power. It carries out malicious cyber activity in order to assert itself aggressively, for example by attempting to interfere in the elections of other countries.”Mr Browder, a former fund manager in Russia who now campaigns against human rights abuses, wants laws to freeze the assets of Russian crooks.The PM’s spokesman said Boris Johnson is “absolutely” confident the Brexit referendum result was fair, adding: “We’ve seen no evidence of successful interference.”Kremlin-backed bots and trolls use tech companies to peddle their fake news in a war on the West.Ministers should “name and shame” Silicon Valley giants who fail to defend themselves.The report said: “Social media companies hold the key and yet are failing to play their part.“The Government must establish a protocol with the companies to ensure they take covert hostile state use of their s seriously.”HOW many wake-up calls do we need before we realise the threat posed by new authoritarian leaders such as Vladimir Putin The Russian Report is a damning document, highlighting Whitehall’s inability to counter new forms of malign state activity.The overwhelming evidence is that government failed to grip the more insidious threats linked to the Russian state with its criminality and money-laundering.The report shows our so-called Rolls-Royce Whitehall machine is more like a Skoda from the days of the Warsaw Pact.It has to change.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kanye wests tears are not a stunt theyre a cry for help
story: Though, let’s face it, stranger things have happened.My second was that Taylor Swt must be sitting back with a smirk and reciting the age old adage of “stand by the river long enough and the bodies of your enemies float by”.For without doubt, Kanye West has made plenty of enemies over the years with his egocentric grand-standing that has been put down to, at best, towering arrogance and, at worst, an uncontrolled narcissism amounting to a God complex.But now, following the deeply uncomfortable footage of him unravelling before an audience in Charleston, South Carolina, in the US, it’s pretty clear that his mental health is in freefall.And his marriage can’t be far behind after he revealed that he and we Kim Kardashian toyed with the idea of aborting their first born North — a horribly insensitive revelation that no child should read on Google.Kanye has long been open about suffering from bipolar disorder and back in  he cancelled a string of tour dates because of a Kim and anyone  close to Kanye faces an uphill battle — as illustrated by his now deleted tweet that his we “had tried to bring a doctor to lock me up”.Like Britney Spears famously shaving her head, Without the tolerance bit.A last-breath act of motherly concern that was perhaps down to the phenomenon known as “hysterical strength” – where human beings suddenly find an extreme power in a le-or-death situation.Either way, how heartbreaking that she couldn’t also save herself.THIS is the cover of Sports Illustrated’s  “swimsuit” issue.Or, in the case of Jasmine Sanders, centre, three strategically placed pieces of dental floss.Doubt she’d hear them from LA anyway.GHISLAINE Maxwell broke down in tears while appearing via video link in a New York court.Reportedly, this was because she was denied bail. Either that or she caught sight of this court sketch.THE sales of packet trle kits have soared during the pandemic as we make a nostalgicto the s favourites of our childhood.As someone who has recently consumed bucketfuls of butterscotch Angel DelightI can concur with this finding, though I draw the line at powdered mash brand Smash.Tinned peaches has been another, resurrected favourite, and I was very excited to find a jar of Sandwich Spread which I adored as a child but now tastes slightly too vinegary for my adult palate.We had ready-made custard in a cardboard carton the other dayand The Bloke had a sandwich filled with Shippam’s “classic” beef spread.Perhaps lockdown has reminded us of family le back when restaurants were solely a treat, takeaways non-existent and we cooked most nights at home before gathering in front of the TV to watch, say, Mike Yarwood. A time when we busied ourselves with playing board games, doing craft activities and reading books during long periods of quiet contemplation with little  to do. And so, consequently, we have gravitated towards the nostalgic food brands that remind us of that time.Though it has to be said that The Bloke’s Heinz Mushroom And Bacon Toast Topper he purchased back in  is a step too far and remains untouched.He was stopped by Border Force teams.Either that or, just like the rest of us, he hired it for an hour and, a few minutes in, drted aimlessly after becoming paralysed with boredom.ONLINE dating frauds have soared by  per cent as con artists exploit loneliness in lockdown then ask to borrow money.The most vulnerable targets were women aged  to .With this in mind, here is my cut-out-and-keep guide to hopefully minimise the chances of this happening to you. If he tells you he’s a spy then he almost certainly isn’t.If he says he’s an airline pilot, only believe it when you see him sitting in a cockpit in full unorm.If he claims all his money is “stuck in Panama”, he’s penniless and after your cash.And finally,he goes incommunicado for several days and claims his phone broke, he’s probably been away with his we and four kids.You have been warned.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: westminster without workers apocalypse opinion
story: For much of the day it looks like the aftermath of a zombie apocalypse movie, with an almost eerie silence.The whole area around Westminster is like this, when normally at this time of year it would be a seething mass of tourists and office workers.It will be some time before we see the tourists again, but what has happened to the thousands of civil servants in their ious departments The answer is that the vast majority of them are working from home.I am told by friends in ious Government departments that while senior civil servants are often now back as normal, the lower ranks are still encouraged to stay away, as long as they can do their work from home.Zoom and Teams are the new tools for the modern official.By and large this country is fortunate in its civil service.Officials are never given the affection reserved for nurses or fire fighters, but we can be thankful that on the whole they are not corrupt or lazy.I share the impatience of some at No with the way the civil service works, but the workers themselves are not the problem.Except that now they are. As long as they are working from home, they are contributing to this country’s problems in three separate ways. The first, and in some ways the most obvious, is that the services they provide are not as good as they should be. I remember fondly that when I was Immigration minister ten years ago, the Passport Service, which in its time had been a national disgrace, won awards for being a model public service.It was quick, flexible and customer friendly.All that has been thrown away under lockdown.There are no appointments in person any more, and I have seen reports that some passports are taking  days to be issued. More than a million passports have expired since March, soyou want to venture abroad next month you may have to be very lucky.If travelling is dficult, driving is not much easier.Anyonewho needs to renew a driving licence is stuck in a long and growing queue.At the other end of the age range, taking your driving test means waiting weeks or months. None of this is good enough in a country aching to get back to normal.The second reason why civil servants should be back at their desks as long as it is safe is that they are often the economic heartbeat of parts of our big cities.Whitehall in London is the most obvious example, but in other cities the public sector is also hugely important for economic activity.Shops, pubs and sandwich bars are open again buttheir customers are miles away they may as well shut their doors once more.As the unlocking has progressed, every MP has been lobbied hard by the sectors who have felt left behind.Gradually the second wave businesses — the nail bars and gyms — are getting their way. But so many of them rely on their location to succeed, and that location works because there are people whose offices are nearby.Empty offices are a death knell for nearby businesses. Footfall is key.The third reason is the most subtle, but perhaps the most important. It is that Government offices need to set an example to the rest of the country.If a private sector employee is wondering whether toto the office, and a neighbour who works for the Government is cheerfully planning to work from home indefinitely, the obvious question arises: “Why should I start commuting again ”Partly for reasons of safety and partly for reasons of convenience, many people have found working from home suits them.This is especially true over the summer, whenyou have a garden it is better to be there two minutes after you stop work than in a sweaty train.What this has come to mean, though, is second-class public services and the throttling of business.It is time for the civil service to set an example.It has had months to make its offices safe, and we have seen the ingenuity of pubs, restaurants and bars in doing the same in much less time, and sometimes with a clientele that will be much less disciplined.So safe offices should now be filling up again, with workers ending those backlogs and restoring the vitality to our cities.Above all they should be sending the signal that Britain can take big steps back towards normal le.A day in the office will mean our streets and shops come back to le.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris mi5 russia
story: The Prime Minister is planning to push ahead with new counter-espionage legislation to make Britain a “harder environment for adversaries to operate in” after the scale of Russias attacks on Britain were revealed.It follows the long-awaited report by Parliament’s Intelligence and Security Committee which confirmed a series of attempts by the Kremlin to interfere in British democracy.The -page document analysed Russian meddling in UK elections and referendums across donations, cyber attacks and even assassinations.He is now set to push for new laws including a formal “register of foreign agents” modelled on the system used in the US and Australia.The American Foreign Agents Registration Act forces spies working on behalf of foreign governments, officials and political parties to register with the US Department of Justice and update them with what they get up to.It was introduced in  in the US to stop foreign agents spreading fascist propaganda.Speaking today, Transport Secretary Grant Shapps confirmed the change was being looked at.He told Sky News: “We are looking at additional powers to look at the activities of hostile states and that may include introducing new laws.“On something like the foreign agent registration laws, that exist in the US and Australia.“This isn’t the end of the road as far as this is concerned, and I do think it’s important that we are aware that states like Russia are not playing by the international rule book.“I urge them to desist in this kind of activity.”Russia has been accused of repeated interventions and attacks on British soil.This includes the Salisbury poisoning attack on spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia, .The ex-KGB spy and his daughter Yulia, , were exposed to a nerve agent and fell gravely ill after having a pizza lunch in Salisbury on Sunday, March , .Russia denied that their special services were involved in the attack, which sparked a diplomatic spat and the expulsion of embassy staff.Yesterdays long-awaited report had demanded new legislation to crack down on foreign spies, and accused the Government of being slow to act.It said: “It has been clear for some time that Russia under Putin has moved from potential partner to established threat, fundamentally unwilling to adhere to international law – the murder of Alexander Litvinenko in  and the annexation of Crimea in  were stark indicators of this.We therefore question whether the Government took its eye off the ball because of its focus on counter-terrorism: it was the opinion of the Committee that until title: qanon conspiracy theory explained
story: The bizarre new pro-Trump theory - known as QAnon - has managed to creep from the dark web into the mainstream.Its supporters claim the President is communicating about covert battles between himself and the Deep State.But what exactly is the theory, how big is its following and why has Twitter banned accounts linked with it  Heres all you need to know about the mysterious movement.QAnon is a conspiracy theory that has taken hold among some Trump supporters.According to NBC, the theory centres around an anonymous source, Q, who is trying to tell the world a secret - or multiple secrets.These centre around unfounded allegations that Donald Trump and special counsel Robert Mueller are waging a secret battle against an alleged paedophile ring.Supporters of the entirely unfounded theory believe that this ring is filled with celebrities and political elites, who have been covertly running the United States government for decades.The theory gained more press coverage after a supporter held a vast letter Q at a Trump rally in Pennsylvania in August .Last month, an armed QAnon follower blocked traffic at the Hoover Dam, demanding the president release a report allegedly tying past presidents Obama and Clinton to the alleged sex ring.The bizarre theory originated in December , when Edgar M.Welch entered a Washington D.C. pizza parlour and demanded to see a basement that did not exist.According to NBC, he believed the restaurant was part of a child sex ring, a conspiracy known as Pizzagate.The US news site reports that eight months later, a person going by Q posted for the first time on the anonymous politics message board chan, known to be a hotbed of conspiracy talk.Since his first message, which involved Hilary Clinton, Q posted nearly , messages.Followers try to decipher these nonsensical posts, with some of Trumps most loyal supporters using them as a way to explain away any scandal the President might face.Jared Holt, a research associate for Right Wing Watch who has followed the growth of QAnon, said: All of Trump’s mishaps on the world stage, his detractors in the media, his ious scandals can all be effectively be framed within the QAnon lore as attacks that are coordinated against him because he’s ever closer to taking down a global conspiracy committing the most atrocious crimes that could be imagined, like Satanic child sex trafficking, and blood sacrice.Most of the deadlines mentioned in Qs posts have been and gone, with all shown to be unfounded.The bizarre theory has gained cult status among some followers, with Q-related products such as T-shirts, mugs and jewellery available.Reddit’s QAnon community GreatAwakening had , subscribers by  - just two years after the theory first surfaced.And conservative celebrities such as Roseanne Barr and Curt Schilling have also referenced its existence, giving it yet more press coverage.Despite originating in the darkest corners of the web, social media sites and online retailers bolstered its image with Amazon having to remove Amazons Choice labels from linked merchandise in . The social media giant announced on Tuesday it had banned , accounts linked with the conspiracy theory.It added it removed , accounts from trends and search features in what is the first time a social media site has taken action against the misinformation.Facebook is understood to be considering taking action too, according to the New York Times.Twitter said it removed the accounts for violating policies on multiple accounts, coordinated abuse and attempting to evade suspensions.A spokesperson said: We’ve been clear that we will take strong enforcement action on behavior that has the potential to lead to offline harm. In line with this approach, this week we are taking further action on so-called ‘QAnon’ activity across the service.We will permanently suspend accounts Tweeting about these topics that we know are engaged in violations of our multi-account policy, coordinating abuse around inidual victims, or are attempting to evade a previous suspension — something we’ve seen more of in recent weeks.The accounts has also become more aggressive and organised in attacking celebrities, NBC reported.

story: NewsopinionDame Donna Kinnair: Nurses deserve a proper pay rise - and shouldnt have to wait to Nurses werent included in this weeks pay rise for public sector workers, because theyre in a three-year deal that ends in April . You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailI take heart from the number of people who saw the list of professions getting a new pay deal this week, and said: ‘What about nursing ’. That demand is testament to the great public support behind us - and we will be demanding fair pay for nursing. But our discussions with government are only just beginning. Politicians across the UK can expect to hear us make the clear case for why nurses and support workers deserve a genuinely signicant pay award and why we won’t wait until next year. You often hear it said that ‘nobody goes into nursing for the money’. And yes, to an extent, our motivations are far dferent. But the more we say this, the more there is a danger that politicians believe that we’re resigned to the low pay. And some of us arenapost just resigned - theyaposre resigning. Some nursing staff are considering leaving the profession they love because they feel it isn’t safe, well respected or fairly paid. I asked my members – half a million of them – how they’ve found working le this year and what could be done to make them feel valued. And their responses reveal a sharp increase in the number thinking of leaving this year, now standing at over a third. Professionals going out the door and taking twenty years of know-how with them. Can the healthcare sector afford that, in this year of all years  For all the tributes in parliament, in speeches or on TV, very few nursing staff feel more valued by politicians.  I don’t doubt the sincerity of their comments but it’s time to match the warm words with cash – a pay rise tops the list of improvements my members need to see. Not a ‘Covid bonus’ but real recognition that, for too many years, the nursing pay hasn’t kept pace with the education and clinical responsibilities of the job.

story: NewsFull extent of Russian meddling laid bare - from assassinations to social mediaThe Prime Minister – who has surrounded himself with Vote Leave architects including Dominic Cummings and Michael Gove – and his Government were accused of an “astonishing lack of curiosity” over claims of Moscow meddlingShareCommentsByChris HughesDefence and Security Editor:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsBoris Johnson and Russias President Vladimir Putin talk during a meeting on the sidelines of an international summit on Libya " %, rgba, rgba, url"What is really going on in politics  Get our daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters.
