You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Boris Johnson is under mounting pressure to order a probe into claims Vladimir Putin’s Russia tried to sway the Brexit referendum. The Prime Minister – who has surrounded himself with Vote Leave architects including Dominic Cummings and Michael Gove – and his Government were accused of an “astonishing lack of curiosity” over claims of Moscow meddling.But Mr Johnson has continued to resist calls for an investigation. Acting Lib Dem leader Ed Davey said Mr Johnson was giving the Russian leader president a “green light” to interfere in UK politics. Yesterday’s publication of a long-delayed Intelligence and Security Committee report warned “Russia considers the UK one of its top Western intelligence targets”.It highlighted espionage and cyber-attacks, election meddling and money laundering. The report also branded the Kremlin’s influence in the UK the “new normal” after successive governments welcomed oligarchs – giving Putin’s allies links “at the highest levels” of British public le. The committee said: “It has been clear for some time Russia has moved from potential partner to established threat, unwilling to adhere to international law. Millions of pounds have been pumped into the Tory Party by wealthy Russians. The Intelligence and Security Committee said: “Several members of the Russian elite who are closely linked to Putin are identied as being involved with charitable and or political organisations in the UK, having donated to political parties, with a public profile which positions them to assist Russian influence operations.” Lubov Chernukhin, , pictured, whose husband Vladimir is an ex Russian minister has given more than £.million to Tory coffers over the past eight years. She is a British citizen and all her political donations are legal. There is no suggestion of any wrongdoing. “The murder of Alexander Litvinenko and the annexation of Crimea were stark indicators. “It was the opinion of the committee that until recently the Government badly underestimated the response required to the Russia threat, and is still playing catch-up.”ISC member Stewart Hosie said the committee “found it astonishing” ministers did not try to shield the EU vote from interference or probe claims of meddling. The SNP MP said: “No one in government knewRussia interfered because they did not want to know.Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said she has “no objection” to an inquiry into interference in the country’s independence referendum. She added governments should not be “complacent” about possible meddling. The ISC report said: “There has been credible open source commentary suggesting that Russia undertook influence campaigns in relation to the Scottish independence referendum in .” Ms Sturgeon said an inquiry was up to the UK Government, but added she did not think the SNP’s values “could be further removed from the values that Vladimir Putin and the Russian regime stand for”. “The UK Government actively avoided looking for evidence. We were told they haven’t seen any, but that is meaninglessthey haven’t looked.” They showed a “lack of curiosity”, Mr Hosie added – especially given claims Russia tried to influence the  US presidential race and Scotland’s vote on independence in . Claims Russian actors were involved in the  EU referendum have dogged the result. Social media firms that fail to tackle the spread of disinformation should be “named and shamed”, the ISC said. “Social media companies hold the key and yet are failing to play their part,” said the committee. “The Government must seek to establish a protocol with the companies to ensure they take covert hostile state use seriously, and have clear timescales within which they commit to removing material.” Ministers said their relationship with social media giants “continues to evolve”. “In the context of the Covid- response, we are learning valuable lessons that will be applied to our future approach to countering disinformation,” the Government said. Yesterday’s heavily redacted, -page report pointed to “widespread” fears about Russian TV channels and web accounts. “Open source studies have pointed to the preponderance of pro-Brexit or anti-EU stories on RT and Sputnik, and the use of bots and trolls,” it said.Ahead of an urgent question in Parliament today, Labour ’s Shadow Home Secretary Nick Thomas-Symonds said the Government had failed “on every level”, to match the “growing threat” from Russia.A furious row reignited over the delay in publishing yesterday’s report. It was drawn up by the previous ISC and sent to Boris Johnson on October . Usually they are published about  days later. This study took another nine months, with No blaming the general election, then the time needed to form a new ISC. But ISC member and Labour MP Kevan Jones blasted claims by the PM it required six weeks to get his confirmation as “categorically not true”. Former ISC chair Dominic Grieve, above, told LBC radio the delay was “inexplicable” and the reasons given by the Government were “just untrue”. Mr Thomas-Symonds said: “The report exposes deep systemic failings in the approach to security. “[It] outlines a litany of hostile state activity, from cyber-warfare, interfering in democratic processes, acts of violence on UK soil and illicit finance. “Little wonder the Government has been so keen to delay publication.” Mr Johnson marks his first anniversary in Downing Street on Friday. Peers’ links to Russian firms come under the spotlight, with the ISC warning they are vulnerable to exploitation by the Kremlin. Second jobs or lucrative directorships with Russian firms have long been seen as evidence Moscow is spreading its tentacles. The report warns: “It is notable a number of members of the House of Lords have business interests linked to Russia, or work directly for major Russian companies linked to the Russian state.These relationships should be carefully scrutinised, given the potential for the Russian state to exploit them.” It noted that MPs must register payments over £ for any work outside Parliament, but “this does not apply to the House of Lords”.Asked yesterdaythe PM believed the referendum result was “fair”, his spokesman said: “Yes. Absolutely.” The Government’s -page response tothe report said: “We have seen no evidence of successful interference in the EU referendum.”Meanwhile Russian IT businessman Aleksej Gubarev, told the High Court he was “stunned” to be linked to a US Democratic Party “hacking incident”.He is suing ex-British spy Chris Steele over a dossier alleging links between Donald Trump and Russia.The murder of former Russian spy Alexander Litvinenko, right, whose tea was laced with deadly polonium- in a Mayfair hotel in , “demonstrated that Russia under President Putin had moved from potential partner to established threat”. The attempted murder of former double agent Sergei Skripal in Salisbury in March  showed Russia was “flouting the most essential of international principles around the prohibition of chemical weapons”. The ISC accused Putin of “flouting UK sovereignty” and “questioned whether the intelligence community has a clear picture of how many Russians there are in the UK who are at risk”. Mr Gubarev said: “I have never been involved with the Russian federal security services or any cyber-attacks on the US Democratic Party.” aposThey focussed on the wrong question,apos says expert An expert who contributed to the report says it has too little evidence of Moscow’s meddling – because it focused “on the wrong questions”. The highly-respected specialist in Russia and its intelligence networks was one of the key witnesses. He has previously advised UK intelligence on how Russia tries to sway public affairs. He believes the report focused too much on “direct” interference such as hacking into systems, largely ignoring attempts to “influence” the UK.

Last night heaposd been out and we were trying to call him home all night but he wasnapost coming back, she said. This morning I got a message from a friend askingthe cat who was found was my cat, and he was. I ran over straight away - it was absolutely heartbreaking, I canapost stop crying. The incident has been especially dficult for five-year-old Logan. Weaposve had Flash for five years, he was my autistic sonaposs first pet and his best friend, the -year-old said. Itaposs hard to explain to my little boy that he isnapost coming back. If Logan was upset or stressed he would give him cuddles. He keeps asking is he going to come back. Kimberley Tinkler, who lives on the street, said the horric attack took place just as people on the street were getting ready for bed at .pm.  We were in the garden and heard a dog across the street barking, she said. We heard a commotion and our eight-year-old neighbour came running into the garden screaming his head off. He was screaming and he wouldnapost stop shaking, the poor lad was traumatised. He said he saw these people let their dog go hell for leather at the cat. Kimberley and her partner went out into the street and saw Flash lying in the road. When we found it they had already run down the street, she said.

title: brides who married grandmothers wedding
story: NewsBrides who married in grandmothers wedding dresses - just like Princess BeatricePrincess Beatrice isn’t the only bride to have chosen a family heirloom dress as their ‘something borrowed’ for their big day - Three women tell The Daily Mirror why they said ‘I do’ in their gran’s vintage dressShareCommentsByAmanda Killelea:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsBride Connie Bell, , never intended to wear her grandma’s dress, but when she took her own wedding dress round to show gran Margaret she decided to try on her -year-old frock and loved it " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPrincess Beatrice became the ultimate modern-day bride when she wore the Queen’s dress for her wedding to Edoardo Mopelli Mozzi. Beatrice won praise for up-cycling the vintage gown worn by her beloved grandmother for a grand state dinner back in . The beautul beaded satin gown only had a few alterations to bring it into the st century, with Beatrice adding some delicate sleeves and removing the underskirts and bubble hem elements. But Beatrice isn’t the only bride to have worn a family heirloom as the “something borrowed” for their big day. Here three women reveal why they also said “I do” in their grans’ vintage frocks. Connie Bell never intended to wear her grandma’s dress. But when she took her own wedding dress to show grandma Margaret, she tried on her gran’s -year-old frock and loved it. Connie, , explains: “When Sam proposed we decided to get married quickly so we had just three months. I looked in a few local shops and picked a dress. I took it round to show my grandma and she joked, ‘Why don’t you try on my dress ’. I did and as soon as I put it on, I loved it. I’m a bit taller so I had to get the skirt ened but other than that it was perfect.” The dress was white satin with a lace overlay and when her grandma Margaret unpacked it from the box in the loft it still had petals of confetti in it from her own big day half a century before.  So Connie put aside the £, dress she had bought from a local bridal shop to wear her gran’s dress for her vintage-themed wedding ceremony, then changed into the new dress for the evening reception. Connie, from Wakefield, West Yorks, adds: “Me and my grandma are best friends so she was thrilled that I wanted to wear her dress.” Connie and Sam, , tied the knot in Harrogate on  November  –  years to the day since her grandparents Margaret and Michael wed. And Connie believes the dress and the wedding date turned into a lucky charm for them.She says: “We had been trying to get pregnant but just a few months after I wore my grandma’s dress we found out I was expecting – and the baby was due on my grandma’s birthday.” Baby Max was born the day after Connie and electrician Sam’s first wedding anniversary. Connie said of Princess Beatrice’s choice of dress: “You would expect a member of the Royal Family to have some expensive designer create a new dress. But I think it is really sweet that she didn’t.”  Bride Thursa Lamoon found her grandmother Barbara’s wedding dress stuffed in the top of a wardrobe when she and her mum were clearing out. Thursa tried the dress on just for fun – but it fit her perfectly and from then on she couldn’t imagine wearing anything  for her own wedding day to husband Jasper. The gown, made from parachute silk, is a real family heirloom having been worn by Thursa’s great aunt and grandma before she walked down the aisle.  But -year-old Thursa, from Gloucestershire, explains: “When I tried it on it was asit had been made for me – my grandma and I must have had similar figures.“My great aunt Lil was a court dressmaker and made dresses for the Royal family and she had made the dress for my grandmother’s sister and then it was passed to Barbara.“It was so well made and had really stood the test of time. I took it to a dressmaker to get it tidied up an it hardly needed anything. “I doubt I could’ve afforded to buy anything so beautul.  “It felt really magical wearing it on my own wedding day. Because my grandma had passed away it felt almost like she was with us.” Thursa and Jasper married in an outdoor ceremony in Malta in , and at first Thursa was worried that the dress would be too warm. “Because it was a beautul silk material it felt really cool and light,” she says. The couple had a special nod to Barbara and husband Clford by having a portrait of their wedding day at the reception. “I adored all the beads and, as I aged, I loved art deco and the s style.  Alison Derrick found her grandmother’s s dress in a brown paper bag when she was a child and immediately declared thatshe ever got married she would wear that dress. “I adored all the beads and, as I aged, I loved art deco and the s style,” she says. “When Robin proposed, I asked my grandmotherI could wear her dress and was so disappointed to see it looking so grey and sad.” So Alison, , enlisted the help of London’s Victoria and Albert Museum to see whether the dress could be revived.  It was lucky she did, as she says: “I took it to the VA and asked their advice, could it be washed  Thank God I didn’t DIY as they said that many of the beads were glycerine and would have collapsed! A dressmaking friend of my mother lined it and it came back to le. The silk is very fragile and the weight of the beads is signicant and they swung so perfectly when I walked.” Nana Elsie married Bob Bowman in Leeds in . Granddaughter Alison recreated her nana’s flapper-style look when she and Robin, now , got married in Kendal, Cumbria, in . Alison completed the s look with a lace headdress, silk stockings and shoes. And Nana Elsie was there – even though she couldn’t see her granddaughter wear her dress as she had sadly lost her sight. Alison says: “The dress was perfect! Every part, that it was my grandmother’s, it was so unusual and I did not waste money on something that would never be worn again – as most others.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA chef who was told by doctors that she’ll never have kids fell pregnant after switching to a vegan diet. Bettina Campolucci Bordi, , was given the devastating news that she unlikely to become a mum after she was diagnosed with polycystic oy syndrome and endometriosis. The influencer was told her chances of conceiving were non-existent while her medical conditions meant Bettina was having mood swings, gained weight, lost chunks of her hair and didnapost have a period for months on end. She said: “After five months of no period, I went to the gynaecologist and thought there would be a straightforward explanation. “I was on my own in the doctor’s office and remember bursting into tears when she told me that the chances of me having kids was non-existent. Having a baby is something we take for granted and I was only in my mid-s. “I was shocked as I thought whatever was wrong with me could be easily fixed. Bettina, who has more than , followers on her Instagram page, @bettinas_kitchen , was offered medication to manage her conditions but a baby was still not on the cards.Both Bettina and her husband had given up on the idea of having a family, but she was determined to tackle the painful symptoms of the PCOS and endometriosis so completely changed her lestyle and diet. At the time, Bettina was working in the food and beverage industry, with long hours and an unhealthy diet .  She gave up meat and all animal-derived products, only bought her goods from farmer’s markets and health shops and cooked everything at home – meaning no processed foods or nasty additives. Bettina also quit her job and started working in the wellness industry, putting together plant-based recipes and hosting cooking retreats. Seven months into her new vegan lestyle, Bettina was overjoyed when she fell pregnant. But due to her history of miscarriages, the budding mum wasn’t out of the woods just yet.  She said: “I was seven months into my new career when I found out I was pregnant. I took a test and went to the doctors. “At first I was confused, but also scared that something might happen, like a miscarriage, which I’ve had before and I was worried it would happen again. “The birth was stressful, too. Two weeks before I was due, I had a kidney infection and ended up in the hospital. They later sent me home but I was still in pain and was booked in for a doctor’s appointment - an hour later, my daughter was in my arms.”Bettina’s adorable daughter is now seven-years-old. She said: “Given my situation, we presumed it wouldnapost happen so of course, she was a hugely welcome surprise. “She is beautul, such a blessing in my le. It’s fantastic being a mum – it’s the hardest job in the world but also the most rewarding. “I do think that my lestyle change was part of why I was able to conceive, not just food-wise but it’s everything around that as well. I did a lot of research and re-educated myself on what might help. I took supplements and started exercising.

Anything that potentially can help ... is a good thing.#xDDonald Trump wears a mask while visiting Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda, Maryland :Brazils coronavirus death toll rises to ,Brazil recorded , additional confirmed cases of the coronavirus in the past  hours as well as , related deaths, its Health Ministry said todayBrazil has registered nearly . million cases of the virus since the pandemic began.The official death toll has risen to ,, according to ministry data.Mourners embrace following a mass burial amid the pandemic in Brazil :Theme park slammed over new rules requiring kids from age three to wear masksA theme park has been slammed by parents over new rules requiring kids from the age of three to wear face masks.Gulliver#xs Valley theme park announced a number of Covid- safe guidelines for using their rides.But some parents were unhappy with the new rules introduced at the park, which opened for the first time on July , as part of the Gulliver#xs Theme Park chain.Read more here.Some families were unhappy with the rules at the theme park :KEY EVENTInsult to heroes as Rishi Sunak warns of pay restraint for NHS and care staffRishi Sunak has sparked fury by warning a million frontline NHS staff they face pay restraints.The Chancellor unveiled hikes up to .% for key workers including doctors and police.But staff such as nurses, #xADparamedics, porters and cleaners, who have also been at the forefront of the heroic battle against Covid-, were left out.They are due a pay review in April, but Mr Sunak warned future rises may be at risk so he can #xCdeliver savings#xD.Poorly paid social care workers also missed out.Read more here.Not everyone on the coronavirus front lines will get a slice of the public sector pay rise :KEY EVENTGovernment guaranteeing £m in loans to Ford UKThe government is guaranteeing #xA million in loans to car giant Ford#xs British arm to secure UK manufacturing jobs. The figure is an increase of , cases from the previous count. It also said the number of deaths had risen by  to ,.People walk on the street in Miami Beach, Florida :NHS staff say they were bulliedthey complained about working conditionsStaff caring for dying Covid- patients at a major UK teaching hospital were subject to a campaign of bullying and abusethey dared complain about working conditions, a union has said. Health care workers at the Queen#xs Medical Centre in Nottingham were shouted at and barred from taking sick leave by managers, Unison claimed.Staff described being openly shouted at on the ward and denied vital personal protective equipment which was kept in a locked office, the union said. Others were allegedly told their le would be made #xCa living hell#xDthey spoke out, and some are now understood to be off sick due to stress.Non-specialist staff were trying to act as palliative carers in unprecedented conditions with no support from the wider Nottingham University Hospitals Trust, it is claimed. Managers created a #xCsickness board#xD in the break room, the union said, listing everyone#xs inidual symptoms to shame staff into coming in to work eventhey were feeling unwell. Unison is now raising a collective grievance on behalf of more than  employees at the trust who were reassigned to look after coronavirus patients at the Queen#xs Medical Centre. The centre is the UK#xs second-largest teaching hospital. One member of staff said: #xCWe were caring for people as they died, using our own phones to Facetime their families, bagging their bodies and then dealing with their relatives. #xCIt was incredibly stressful.#xD:Oath of allegiance held virtually for first time everThe ancient tradition of new bishops paying homage to the sovereign has been carried out virtually for the first time in history. The Queen received the oath of allegiance from the newly-appointed Archbishop of York during a video call on Tuesday, Buckingham Palace said. Normally, new bishops pay homage to the Queen in person, before they begin their duties, but the coronavirus pandemic has meant the Queen has been carrying out some of her usual audiences online or on the phone. Updating a -year-old custom, the Queen held a video-call from Windsor Castle with The Most Reverend and Rt Hon Stephen Cottrell to receive the oath. The act of newly-appointed bishops paying homage to the sovereign dates back to the reign of Elizabeth I, and the Palace confirmed it is the first time this has happened virtually. The oath acts as the bishop#xs formal acknowledgement of allegiance to the monarch, who is the Supreme Governor of Church of England. Archbishop Stephen was confirmed as Archbishop of York on July .The -year-old monarch has been staying at Windsor in Berkshire for the past  weeks since before lockdown.:Man fined £, for breaching lockdown rules after sneaking off to get haircutA man has been fined #xA, for breaching lockdown after sneaking out to get a haircut.Gareth Le Monnier, , was so desperate for a trim he flouted self-isolation rules to visit Toni  Guy when he arrived on the Channel Island of Guernsey.The -year-old, who will not be allowed out of jail until he pays the fine, was slammed by a judge, who told him that understanding the rules was #xCnot rocket science.#xDRead more here.He breached his isolation rules to get a chop :More could be done to suppress the spread of coronavirus ahead of winterMore could be done to suppress the spread of coronavirus ahead of winter, with one positive case per million people as a possible goal, an expert has said. Speaking at the House of Lords Science and Technology Committee on Tuesday, Sir Venki Ramakrishnan, who is the president of the Royal Society, said that while the Government#xs policy was to keep the virus transmission rates as low as possible, he added that perhaps elimination, which would involve #xCone case in a million#xD, should be #xCa stated goal or at least an aspiration#xD. He cited the example of how Scotland, which is thought to be following an #xCelimination approach#xD to tackle the disease, currently has a much lower infection rate than England. Sir Venki said: #xCIf you look at the situation in Scotland versus England today, the total number of cases per capita is about comparable, which means that in the early stages of the pandemic, the two countries had a very similar outcome. #xCButyou look at the infection rate today, Scotland is about  times lower than England.#xDHe added: #xCI think we could be doing more to suppress the virus more completely before we go into the winter, and that would give us much more leeway. #xC#xCIt would also make a lot of the environments safer,for example, schoolshospitals which we were worried about.#xD:Driving tests resume in England on WednesdayDriving tests restart in England on Wednesday with a huge backlog after hundreds of thousands were delayed or cancelled due to the coronavirus lockdown. The Driver and Vehicle Standards Agencyurged candidates to ensure they have #xChad enough practice#xD before taking the test. Driving tests were suspended across the UK in March in a bid to slow the spread of Covid-. Those learners whose tests were cancelled are being invited to re-book first when they resume in England. DVSA chief driving examiner Mark Winn said: #xCI know many learners are keen to take their driving test but it is vital they have the right skills and knowledge to help them through a letime of safe driving before attempting it. #xCLearners should practice driving on a iety of roads and in dferent driving conditions so they are well prepared for driving independently.#xDDrivers will be soon be able to take tests :London bus lanes could be in operation  Bus lanes in London are to be operational at all times under a plan to support passengers travelling outside peak hours. Transport for London said extending their hours will #xChelp guard against a damaging car-led recovery#xD by making bus journey times more reliable and improve safety for cyclists.A trial of the measure will take place in late summer. Bus lanes can be used by all vehicles when they are not operational, which is generally outside peak travel times.TfL said it is planning to change the rules as demand for buses is #xCspreading throughout the day#xD as part of a sht away from travel at traditional rush hours. Its figures show that in  , some . billion journeys were made on bus routes that would benefit from the proposed amendment.:KEY EVENTCoronavirus UK death toll rises to , as another  people dieThe UK#xs death toll is now at , after a further  people died with coronavirus.The figure is for all settings, including hospitals, care homes and the wider community.The Government also said in the -hour period up to am on Tuesday, there had been a further  lab-confirmed cases.Separate figures published by the UK#xs statistics agencies show there have now been , deaths registered in the UK where Covid- was mentioned on the death certicate.Overall, a total of , cases have been confirmed.The death toll continues to tick upwards:Revised methodology on Covid- deaths to be published soonHealth Secretary Matt Hancock said Public Health Englandwill #xCvery, very shortly#xD publish a #xCrevised methodology#xD on accurately measuring Covid- deaths. #xCAt the start it was perfectly reasonable to say thatsomebody had ever registered positive with Covid and died, they died from Covid,#xD he told the Commons Science and Technology Committee. #xCFor the first few weeks of the crisis and indeed in the peak, that was a perfectly reasonable thing to do. However, that is no longer reasonable. #xCBecauseyou have Covid in March and fully recovered, or even were asymptomatic and now die of something completely dferent, then the way it was being measured until last week counted that as a death with Covid, that clearly is no longer appropriate and PHE are currently reviewing that time series.#xD Askedthe review by PHE was in place already, Mr Hancock said: #xCThey#xll publish very, very shortly a revised methodology for how to get an accurate measure of deaths with Covid.#xD:Barcelona limits number of beach-goers amid fears of second waveBarcelona authorities have cut the number of people allowed on to the city#xs beaches to , from ,, after crowds flocked to the sea at the weekend - despite advice to stay home to curb a local rise in coronavirus infections. Barcelona would typically have around , people on its ten beaches at this time of year, a city spokeswoman said. However, it is at the heart of an increase in coronavirus cases that followed the end of Spain#xs national state of emergency one month ago. In response, local and regional authorities have imposed a string of restrictions, to the fury of some businesses which have been told to close their doors again, including cinemas, nightclubs and gyms in Barcelona. #xCWhy do we have to be closed #xD, said Oscar Simon, the head of a martial arts school, speaking at a protest by sports centre managers and workers. #xCWe cannot cope with this crisis, three more months closed will send us to our death,#xD Simon said, stressing he had spent a lot of money in protective equipment that guaranteed health standards.People enjoying the warm weather in Barcelona :Around , lives may be lost to cancer over the next five yearsAround , lives may be lost to four common cancers over the next five years due to delays in diagnosis caused by Covid-, experts have said. A drop-off in the number of people seeing their GP with symptoms, and lower referrals for scans, could result in cancer being spotted too late, according to research published in The Lancet Oncology. Even when people are referred to hospital, there are growing delays in accessing diagnostic services that could save lives, the study warned. This combined effect means there must be a rapid ramping up of NHS diagnostics to prevent further avoidable deaths.NHS figures show that , urgent cancer referrals were made by GPs in England in May , down from , in May  - a fall of %.At the same time, , more people are now waiting to have key cancer tests in England#xs hospitals compared with the same point last year.:Coronavirus may be more severe in colder monthsCoronavirus may be more severe in colder months than warmer ones, and dry indoor air may encourage its spread, new research suggests. Severe Covid- outcomes decreased as the pandemic progressed from winter to the warmer months, analysis indicates. Experts warn that their findings paint a grim picture for the colder weather, when it is thought the disease may re-emerge.Researchers analysed data from , patients admitted to hospital with Covid- in Croatia, Spain, Italy, Finland, Poland, Germany, the UK and China. They mapped this against local temperature and estimated indoor humidity and found that severe outcomes - being taken to hospital, admittance to ICU or the need for ventilation - dropped in most European countries over the course of the pandemic, covering the transition from winter to early summer. The study, which has not been peer-reviewed, suggests there was a corresponding decrease in the rate of deaths from the disease. There was roughly a % drop in mortality for every one degree Celsius rise in temperature, the King#xs College London researchers say. By contrast, the severity of symptoms and mortality rate remained constant in China during the first wave of the pandemic, which occurred solely throughout the winter. The study also looked at data from more than , UK users of the Covid Symptom Study app reporting symptoms consistent with Covid-.:Children under  to become eligible for coronavirus testsChildren under the age of five with potential coronavirus symptoms will be able to access testing for the virus from Wednesday. So far, a test has been carried out on under-fives onlythere is a pressing clinical need to do so.With childcare settings reopening from July , the Scottish Government has reviewed the policy to avoid households having to isolate unnecessarily.From July , under-fives will be eligible for routine testing through all routes including drive-in regional testing centres, mobile testing units and by ordering a home test kit. Dr Gregor Smith, interim chief medical officer, told the Scottish Government#xs coronavirus briefing: #xCWe know that young children can become infected with Covid-, but are unlikely to have severe symptoms. #xCAt the current time, the evidence suggests that it#xs very unusual for the infection to be transmitted among children, and from children to adults.#xDMore OnCoronavirus

Claire Reynolds and Ben Binks, both , decided to go all in when they saw a detached home in Ossett, near Wakefield, as the prize in a raffle.The couple bought £ of tickets in the hopes of having a home of their own for the first time, Yorkshire Live reported.Now Claire, Ben and their three kids Alfie, , Riley,  and Hudson, two, are due to move into the £, property, which is less than  minutes from their current place. They also will pick up the keys to a plush £, Volvo SUV. The organiser of the raffle, Dale Tate, decided to put the house up for grabs having failed to find a buyer. The -year-old is overjoyed with having sold , tickets for £ each and for who won the top prize. He said: The family is the most deserving family. We met them yesterday and they have been through some pretty hard times as two of their boys have got health issues and we really couldnapost have asked for a nicer family for this to happen to. They live on a council estate and donapost own their own home so this really is just a fairytale ending. It could have been anybody but it was a family who live in Tingley which was just complete pot luck as we had zero influence. We had messages from people in America, Canada, Australia and the draw was done fairly and they are deserving winners. Mr Tate and his we Kathy endured a stressful  days while the raffle was ongoing.They were constantly responding to messages - including those from trolls which accused them of scamming people - and even poured their own money into setting up advertising posts on Facebook to make more people aware of the raffle.It was a massive risk for us because people donapost realise what goes on in the background, Mr Tate said.  We havenapost slept for a month and we have been hounded by people saying this fraud and that the house will go to my uncle or brother. We got it   but we had to shut people down and reply to everyone. It was only when people read our comments they realised that we were real people. We had to put so much work into getting the raffle into Facebook groups and we only had a limited amount of time to sell it so we had to put our own savings into Facebook advertising and that was a massive risk. Now Mr Tate is planning to buy a campervan so he can take his boys, who are two, five, seven and nine, around the UK before they embark on a new adventure in Australia. We are going to purchase a second-hand VW campervan as Iaposve always promised my kids that I will take them camping, he said.  Weaposre going to go around the UK and pull up at dferent locations and see the country for the last time. We leave in early September so weaposre going to go round and see family and say our goodbyes too. Kathy is from Brisbane so weaposre going to settle there and take it easy and live a more laid-back le and spend more time with the kids. Mr Tate thanked everyone who took part in the raffle.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA theme park has been slammed by parents over new rules requiring kids from the age of three to wear face masks. Gulliveraposs Valley theme park announced a number of Covid- safe guidelines for using their rides. But some parents were unhappy with the new rules introduced at the park, which opened for the first time on July , as part of the Gulliveraposs Theme Park chain. The current government advice states that anyone under the age of  doesnapost need to wear a face mask. Yet in guidance on the chainaposs website, it states: We have asked that all those aged  years and above wear face-coverings whilst using the rides and attractions. Face coverings can take the form of neck gaiters, summer scarves or bandanas, but do not need to be face ‘masks’. Children under  years of agecollectively form a very small minority of our total audience, thus naturally reducing the number of interactions with staff members and hence lowering transmission risk to an absolute minimum. Please be assured that we believe this additional temporary safety measure to be no less equal to other pre-existing safety measures such as minimum height restrictions and the ability to use safety restraints.On the companyaposs Facebook page criticised the new rules, saying they were unnecessary for young kids. Sophie Gillett wrote: I don’t think my just turned  year old will keep a mask or face covering on - he lasted  seconds in the shop yesterday before he took it off. Debbie Cartwright wrote: I wonapost be visiting with my  year old whilst this policy is in place either. There is no way he would keep one on. And Laura Chapman wrote: This is an absolute joke. Will definitely not be visiting whilst these ludicrous rules are in place.  There is scientic evidence and countless studies against children and masks, and about the potential psychological impact of this on children. Shame on you gullivers world! And shame on the people supporting this! However, others said they were happy about the rules, with one person writing: We visited yesterday and my youngest just turned  never worn a mask but every time we went on a ride asked for his mask and wore it without any complaint. I work for NHS so know under s not required to wear but totally complied with Gulliveraposs requirements and had the best family day out. Highly recommend. Thanks to all the amazing Gulliveraposs staff.  Another family agreed, commenting: We went yesterday and had an amazing day. My kids werenapost bothered about wearing face masks for the rides, hands regularly washed and sanitised.  will not stop us having fun and making memories.Julie Dalton, managing director of Gulliver’s Valley Theme Park Resorts, told Sun Online Travel : Following feedback from our guests and our staff, we have introduced a system for those unable to wear face-coverings, to indicate this at the time of pre-booking.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA one-year-old boy was left in agony when he stepped on a red-hot disposable barbecue buried in sand on a holiday beach. Harryaposs mum Stephanie Rogers said the youngster started screaming after the accident in Exmouth in Devon and needed urgent treatment. She said: I picked him up and couldnapost see anything that could have caused it. My husband recoiled with his hand because the sand was incredibly hot. It was scorching. My husband got a shovel to have a look and it turned out there was a barbecue under there. I have no idea how long it had been there. Itaposs complete laziness and complete stupidity. There must be plenty of ways to dispose of the barbecue or take it home. Harry, of Guildford, Surrey, been playing happy as a sandboy on the beach when he trod on the hidden BBQ left by other people. He had to be rushed to hospital with second-degree burns and large blisters. His parents say he is still in a lot of pain but they hope the wounds will heal and he wonapost be scarred for le. It was awful, really awful. Iaposm a first time parent, he is my only child, and you feel completely helpless said his mum. It was just so distressing. I canapost begin to explain how gut-wrenching these cries were. So many friendly lovely people were coming up askinghe was OK. It was one of the worst things Iaposve ever experienced. The family are now pleading with beach-goers to dispose of barbecues properly. She said I donapost believe whoever did it was malicious or trying to cause harm.  Earlier this summer emergency crews across the region tackled several fires they say were caused by disposable barbecues and bonfires, despite warnings against them. A campaign to ban the sale of disposable barbecues in Dorset has gained more than ten thousand signatures. It follows the devastating fire in Wareham Forest two weeks ago which destroyed hundreds of hectares of heathland. Firefighters found disposable barbecues at the scene. In July last year another toddler was burnt in almost identical circumstances. Rudy Haslam,  months old, who tried to knock down a sandcastle on a holiday beach faced months of painful physio and could lose movement in his hands. He screamed in agony as he was horrically burnt by carelessly-discarded disposable barbeque.  Little Rudy was rushed to hospital and needed emergency treatment for more than  blisters and burns on his hands. He had tried to knock down what he thought was a sand castle on Porth Iago beach near Aberdaron, North Wales. But the aposcastleapos was in fact a crude attempt to bury the barbeque. In their hurry to get away, whoever left it there had simply scuffed and kicked sand over it. Furious dad Joe, speaking from their home in Warrington, said Rudy had aposlooked like he had put his hands in a bucket of acidapos after he was burnt by the red-hot barbie.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailRamps for disabled people were first constructed by the ancient Greeks, an archaeologist claims. Access slopes at a range of buildings, including healing sanctuaries and temples, are the earliest evidence of civilisations adapting to help less-mobile citizens, said Debby Sneed. Examples date from as far back as the early th century BC – but their true purpose has not been recognised till now, she believes. Dr Sneed said that although ramps were common in Greek buildings, their presence has previously been neglected in research. They have wrongly been viewed as a “means of conveying sacricial animals”, she added, and have often been missing from building plans in scholarly articles. While the provision of access to mobility-impaired iniduals may not have been the exclusiveof these ramps, it was a primary factor in their construction, she said. She found such ramps were particularly common at healing sanctuaries, where the disabled sought help from the god of medicine, Asclepius. The Temple of Asclepius at Epidaurus had at least  stone ramps, she noted. Greece was often at war during that era and would have had many wounded soldiers, Dr Sneed wrote in a paper for Antiquity, the journal of archaeology.

story: It’s a player’s dream for a new manager to come in and say they’ll all get a chance to prove themselves, so credit goes to Micky Mellon for doing just that at Dundee United.However, with two weeks until the new Premiership season starts and no new first-team recruits in the door, United fans would be forgiven for feeling a little anxious.Besides the addition of young reserve goalkeeper Jack Newman it’s been all quiet in terms of ins and outs at Tannadice as new boss Mellon assesses his squad.Not even a fortnight in the hot seat himself, he is well within his rights to do just that.He needs to have an informed opinion of what he has at his disposal and where he may need to strengthen.That comes from seeing players up close and in the flesh, watching them in sessions and in games but also getting to know them as people.These are all important steps for a new regime to get maximum results.I fear, though, by leaving it too late the Tangerines could get off to sticky start on the pitch under Mellon.Don’t get me wrong, there is a lot of talent in that Terrors pool as it stands.In Lawrence Shankland you have a prolic marksman and potential star in the making for club and country.Liam Smith, Jamie Robson, Nicky Clark and Paul McMullan will be itching to show what they can do at the highest level.Americans Dillon Powers and Ian Harkes provide good options and there’s young talent like Louis Appere, Declan Glass and Logan Chalmers, too.That’s not to mention experienced campaigners like Benjamin Siegrist, Mark Connolly, Mark Reynolds and Calum Butcher, who United have relied on for the last  months.They have all stepped up to the plate and handled that responsibility to earn United their spot at the top table and deserve the chance to defend it.However, going into the Premiership for the first time in four years, I still feel United are a little thin on the ground.Quality is, of course, more important than quantity and I’m sure Mellon will have his targets title: children under five to be tested for covid 19 as education secretary promises quick access for pupils and teachers
story: Children under the age of five with potential coronavirus symptoms will be able to access testing for the virus from Wednesday.Health officials previously only carried out tests on under-fivesthere was a pressing clinical need to do so but the Scottish Government has reviewed its position due to the reopening of childcare settings last week.In a move which it is hoped will prevent households being forced to isolate unnecessarily, children will now be eligible for routine testing through drive-in regional testing centres, mobile testing units and home test kits.Dr Gregor Smith, interim chief medical officer, told the Scottish Government’s coronavirus briefing: “We know that young children can become infected with Covid-, but are unlikely to have severe symptoms.“At the current time, the evidence suggests that it’s very unusual for the infection to be transmitted among children, and from children to adults.#Dr Smith said it would be important to know whether a child#s symptoms are being caused by the virus as changing restrictions increase the number of ways younger children are able to mix.He saida child tests positive, they will need to isolate for seven days from the onset of symptoms and household members will be asked to isolate for  days.Meanwhile, education secretary John Swinney pledged pupils and teachers who develop symptoms will have quick access to testing when schools reopen.He also revealed plans for a surveillance programme for potential infection in schools and other “vital health measures” including guidance for what should happencoronavirus cases are discovered.More details will be confirmed on Wednesday but Mr Swinney said schools will only be allowed to reopen fullythe Scottish Government believes the spread of coronavirus has been adequately suppressed, with a final decision to be announced on July .Mr Swinney was also asked whether a recent spike in new coronavirus cases in parts of Scotland could prohibit theof schools.The Scottish Government believes an outbreak at the Sitel call centre in Lanarkshire was responsible, at least in part, for  coronavirus new cases being recorded overnight on Tuesday. It had been doing tracing work for NHS England.mdash Lesley-Anne KellyJuly , Mr Swinney said: #If we find ourselves in a situation where we are not able to effectively suppress the virus, then the opening of schools is called into question.“We’re working very, very hard on all fronts to suppress the virus and to make sure we have all of the preparations in place for the restart of schools in August.”First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said all new cases are being looked into and steps taken to trace contacts and break the chains of transmission.She said she was #concerned# at reports of staff breaching social distancing guidelines, adding: “We all have to constantly remind ourselves of the importance of this in our own social interactions.”The SNP leader also addressed the rise in the number of new cases in recent days, with  new cases reported on Saturday,  on Sunday, falling to seven on Monday then rising to  on Tuesday.She said: “These figures are a sharp reminder of something that you’ve heard me say on a regular basis in Scotland – that the virus is still there.“That said, a great deal of work is being done, not least through Test and Protect, to understand all of these cases, follow up contacts of them and make sure that all necessary and appropriate steps are being taken to break the chains of transmission.”She added: “We all have a part to play in keeping this virus under control.”The Evening Express is committed to providing news to our communities.Right now that’s more important than ever, which is why our key content is free.You can chose to support us and access premium content by subscribing to the Evening Express from just £. a month. blaize_config   n t t tCancellation Offer % - title: memories of iconic aberdeen pub wanted for new book
story: Memories of an iconic Aberdeen pub are being sought for a new book.A cultural association want to publish a compilation about the Blue Lamp, whose owner Sandy Brown recently passed away.Bridge of Dub has started a campaign to collect stories, anecdotes and creative expressions about the popular venue.The Blue Lamp, located in Gallowgate, was widely recognised as one of the best jazz venues in the UK.A selection of the best stories will be published in a book that aims to preserve the legacy of the venue.The idea for it came after Sandy Brown passed away in April this year, with this project being fully supported by his family.Andrea Baggio from Bridge of Dub said: “During the last weeks, after Sandy passed away, Facebook was full of posts that started: #I remember that time when##, #once Sandy told me that## or #I always would have liked to##“These memories and heritage are very important to the City of Aberdeen and to the music community that the Blue Lamp and its owner represented for so many years.”“For this reason, it is vital to collect all of these stories and turn them into something that will leave a lasting legacy.“We will be creating a book to bind this collection of memories that we hope will pay homage that Sandy and the Blue Lamp community deserve.”The association encourages everyone to submit a maximum of , words to bridgeofdub@hotmail by July You can use the format of an anecdote, a short story, a poem, or any other creative idea.This initiative is non-profit and self-funded as a way to honour Sandy Brown#s memory.Any profit will be used to fund a memorial concert or donated to a charity.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancellation Offer % - title: north east mp accuses government of lack of clarity over oil and gas deal
story: An Aberdeen MP says he is #alarmed# by UK ministers# failure to commit to a sector deal for oil and gas.Stephen Flynn, the MP for Aberdeen South, pressed business and industry minister Nadhim Zahawi to commit to delivering a deal for the offshore industry by the end of the year.Experts fear around , jobs could eventually be lost in the sector in the coming months as a result of the Covid- pandemic and the collapse of the price of oil.Mr Flynn urged ministers to deliver a deal to support the industry in its transition away from oil and gas as soon as possible # and said delaying until autumn would be #too late#.After calling on the Government to #give back# to the north-east through a sector deal, Mr Flynn said there was a #lack of clarity# on the issue.He said: “Tory Ministers have previously refused to put a formal timescale on the delivery of a sector deal but with all the positive efforts being made by the sector I had hoped they could at least confirm their intention to finalise a deal by the end of the year at the latest.“The response I received provided an astounding lack of clarity on the future of the long promised sector deal # let’s not beat about the bush, anything beyond the autumn, let alone the end of the year, will be too late.“Hardly a week has gone by without redundancy headlines and I’ve taken every opportunity to demand this Tory Government step up to the plate.“Last month the Scottish Government delivered £ million of investment in the sector, now it’s time the UK Government make good on their promise of support. Having raked in over £ billion in revenue from the industry, it’s high time that the Treasury gave back.”Plans are already under way to help the north-east move away from reliance on oil and gas, and an energy transition zone # a business park focusing on renewables # is planned for the area around Aberdeen#s new South Harbour.In response to Mr Flynn, Mr Zahawi said: #It is a manesto commitment of this Government to deliver an oil and gas sector deal.#We are working with the sector and the Minister for Energy has been engaging constantly with the sector to make sure they can actually take the opportunities that are before them in offshore wind generation and all sorts of areas.#Of course, hydrogen is going to be incredibly important to the energy White Paper we publish in the autumn.#Industry body Oil and Gas UKsaid it is in discussions with the Government over a possible deal.Stakeholder and communications director, Gareth Wynn, said: “OGUK is discussing a transformational sector deal with the UK Government. It has jobs, the supply chain and energy communities at its core and will also set out how the UK’s oil and gas industry will play its part to support a green recovery working together with Government.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancellation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Evening Express website including all Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening Express n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb and ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayUnlimited access to all articles on the Evening Express website. title: plans approved for aberdeen flats development
story: Plans for a new residential development in a city community have been approved.Council officials have given the green light for the project, which will see  affordable flats built in a five-storey block on Pittodrie Street.Architects Halliday Fraser Munro, which submitted the planning application to Aberdeen City Council last year, say the development has been designed to complement the surrounding area, which largely consists of student accommodation.The firm says the new block will form a #continuous street frontage# with existing buildings in the area.The project will also include a shared garden for the block, while street trees will also be planted # similar to those already on Pittodrie Street.A statement submitted in support of the application reads: #The proposed development has been designed to complement the surrounding buildings to create a coherent urban block.#The block has been positioned on the site to front onto Pittodrie Street to create a continuous street frontage to relate to the student residences and the typical building pattern of the surrounding residential tenement blocks.#The site access is taken from Pittodrie Street and is positioned to the east side of the site to relate to the location of the car parking and service area of the neighbouring student residences.#Planting will be introduced along Pittodrie Street to continue the street trees that have been implemented as part of the student residences. Low level hedging is also proposed along Pittodrie Street to create a small planted buffer between the street and the proposed building.#The development is designed to a high quality to provide an attractive and sustainable development that will enhance the Pittodrie area.#Permission was granted by council planners, subject to a number of conditions relating to matters such as contamination, building materials and parking.The site for the development is owned by William NicolLimited, and was previously home to a since-demolished warehouse.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancellation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Evening Express website including all Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening Express n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb and ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayUnlimited access to all articles on the Evening Express website. title: aberdeen boss derek mcinnes praises squads commitment to fitness as he explains surprising bleep test results
story: Derek McInnes has praised the professionalism of his players as they step up preparations for the new season.Aberdeen start their campaign a week on Saturday against Rangers at Pittodrie.The Dons have been back in pre-season for five weeks having been off for three months after the coronavirus pandemic resulted in football being shutdown in mid-March.However, even during lockdown, the Reds’ squad continued to work on their fitness and McInnes was pleased with the condition of his players when they ed.He said: “We did our first test, the bleep test that we normally do on our first day back coming back from a shorter break, we did that after two weeks.“One or two of the younger ones could have done better, but by and large the majority were ahead in their yardage covered from when they’re normally tested, that’s an indication that they’ve been working hard in isolation.“We had to furlough our players, we kept some of our players off of furlough to do the community work that the club’s been doing, but the majority were furloughed for a period of time.“Up until then the work they were doing was very competitive and to a very high level, it’s a credit to the players for how focused they were and how professional they are, there’s a pride there.“I do think it comes down to an inidual pride, players don’t want to be embarrassed and don’t want to be the first dropping out of the bleep test.“I do think what we’ve created over the years is a culture of what’s expected, there are guys that know what’s expected and I think that professional pride must be there and part of a player’s make up.“If that professional pride isn’t there then you will find yourself playing at a lower level before too long.”This pre-season has been dferent to any other with no contact allowed between players during the first fortnight.Since then top flight sides have been able to scale up their training, however, with their last game being a - win against Hibs at Pittodrie on March , it has been important not to push players too hard too early.McInnes added: “In terms of competitive football, from us beating Hibs at Pittodrie and us playing Rangers, it will be the best part of five months.“We were restricted for the first couple of weeks of training with no contact so we had to work in small groups.“The sports scientists and medical team were at pains to stress the importance of not being too much normal training early on as the players hadn’t really had any football work, even passing or shooting.“They had done a lot of running and a lot of work in isolation.“Clearly when you saw the boys come back they were dferent animals. They were actually looking leaner because they hadn’t been doing all their power and gym work.”Trying to avoid injuries during pre-season has been key for McInnes and, despite a few knocks, in the main Aberdeen’s players have come through unscathed.Defender Mikey Devlin is the only player set to be missing at the start of the season after sustaining a hamstring injury last week.McInnes said: “It was a case of being kind to them and building them up gradually and being mindful that we didn’t want to pick up too many injuries.“In my conversations I’ve had with other managers in recent weeks, they have all faced similar situations where little aches and strains is having an impact on numbers.“That is to be expected. We were picking up little injuries in the first couple of weeks and we think that is a consequence of getting them moving again.“We are now coming out of that thankfully. We got through the game on Saturday and the numbers were looking more like it in terms of squad strength.“There is no doubt it was a balancing act.“This is the longest these boys would have had in their careers of not kicking a ball and training together.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancellation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Evening Express website including all Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening Express n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb and ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayUnlimited access to all articles on the Evening Express website. title: letters to the editor june 26 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,In publishing the opinion piece #All lives matter# from your contributor on page  of the June  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser, you have demonstrated a profound lack of understanding of the current Black Lives Matter protests.The tone-deaf piece is an attempt by your contributor to shut down engagement and perpetuate ignorance.How anybody can make the claim that all lives matter after witnessing such horric police brutality is beyond belief.All lives cannot matter until Black Lives Matter.Instead of deflecting and diluting the conversation, surely it is time to educate ourselves about what is happening, and to fight systemic injustice Madeleine Conn, ArdrishaigSir,The SNP continues to demonstrate its economic incompetence.New figures show the SNP government underspent its budget by a quarter of a billion pounds in -, and failed to use £ million of borrowing capacity. ​Instead of demanding further borrowing powers and more funding from the UK Government, the separatists should learn to use the resources they already have.With such colossal mismanagement, it#s no surprise that even senior SNP advisor Andrew Wilson has stated that Scotland is set to be the worst performing economy in the developed world. Once again, the separatists# numbers simply don#t add up.Councillor Alastair Redman # Kintyre and Islands wardSir,Exactly two years ago I was diagnosed with stage three, oestrogen positive breast cancer.I’d just come back from a week#s holiday in Spain with Isabel and Margaret. Days before I went on holiday I’d had a biopsy following referral from my GP. Although there wasn’t a cloud in the sky, my holiday was definitely clouded by impending results#I had chosen to wait until after my holiday to get them.The journey that Monday to go to Gartnavel is one I’ll never forget. My partner Frank didn’t shut up the whole way there, obviously he was nervous. I couldn’t be bothered with the small talk and just wanted him to shut up. Obviously I was nervous and he was just trying to keep my mind off it, but I was too busy silently praying. The number  is something I see all the time so I spent the whole journey looking for the number on someone’s licence plate #I saw it everything would be ok. I didn#t see it. That might sound a bit daft, but fear does crazy things to you.Walking into the consultant#s room and finding a nurse waiting there confirmed my worst fears. #It’s a wee cancer,# said Mr Wilson. The words echoing in my head, I couldn’t hear anything after that. I remember taking a deep breath and looking at Frank. I will never, ever forget the look on his face.My only question that day was #am I going to lose my breasts # The answer was no, and thankfully Frank was there to take in what was being said my head was spinning. The question I really wanted to ask was #am I going to die # I was too scared to ask that question.I didn’t cry until I walked out the hospital, then I bawled. Frank was amazing, and he didn’t talk like a budgie on the way home.The journey home was horrendous. I was terried about telling my mum. How do you tell your mum that her only child has cancer  I hadn’t told her anything about finding a lump. I couldn’t cope with worrying about her worrying about me # butit happens again I#d do it dferently and she’ll be the first to know. By the time I got home I had no more tears left.The relief telling mum was a huge weight off my shoulders. What ensued after my initial diagnosis was two weeks of crying every day. Telling the girls at work was so emotional, and in fact I was exhausted with it all.Once surgery and treatment plans were in place I was in a better place. Time to get the head down and get on with it, and that#s what I did. I was full of positivity and determination, and I think my sense of humour helped enormously.The treatment was bad, but it was necessary. The ongoing treatment is bad but it#s necessary. I’m alive and that’s what matters. My le has changed forever, nothing will be the same. My le has been ided into Before Cancer and After Cancer  I now have a new #normal#.I don’t know what the future holds, who does, but I intend to live my le happily, positively and most definitely to the fullest!I will never forget the support, both physically and emotionally that I received from my nearest and dearest, and of course from the whole community. The strength you have given me continues, and for that I am truly grateful.Please, pleaseyou find an abnormality or you just feel something isn’t quite right, act upon it and seek attention.I know it’s a dficult time with this horrid virus but it’s important to remember that early detection saves lives.Stay safe and take care.Yvie Young, Lochgilphead

title: wealth of shinty pictures uncovered in furnace
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsA treasure trove of old shinty photos has been unearthed in Furnace after lying in a suitcase for decades.The photograph collection belonged to former Furnace and Lochfyneside player, the late Niven #Bunty# Crawford, and turned up earlier this month when his daughter Christine Crawford was having a lockdown clearout.Christine#s nephew and Bunty Crawford#s grandson Scott Robertson told the Advertiser his grandfather#s story.Bunty Crawford was born and raised in Minard.Just before the Second World War he was taking a course at Glasgow University School of Art # and was in demand as a shinty player. While in the city he played for the university, and in fact played in the   Littlejohn Vase final.He joined the Royal Naval Reserve and on the outbreak of war was posted to the Royal Navy destroyer HMS Icarus. Aboard the Icarus, he saw action in the Norwegian campaign, including the the Battle of Narvik, during  and was involved in the Dunkirk evacuation.After the war Bunty ed to finish his university qualication, and married ChristinaMacCallum from Furnace in .Bunty and his young we settled in Furnace where they had three children, John, Moira and Christine. He turned out in goals for Lochfyneside shinty team, playing in the  and  Camanachd Cup finals # losing out to Newtonmore on both occasions.Lochfyneside disbanded in the s and reverted to the old Furnace club. It was at that point Bunty, a painter and decorator, stepped back from playing. He continued to follow shinty over the years often accompanied his friend, neighbour, fellow war veteran and Lochfyneside team-mate Jimmy Sinclair.Bunty was a keen photographer and recorded many matches and occasions which would otherwise have been left to the memories of the people who were there. He also captured priceless images of shinty characters now long gone but fondly remembered.He died in  at the age of .Scott himself has been a stalwart of Inveraray Shinty Club for three decades and a member of the team, along with his brother David, which lted the Camanachd Cup in .Hid grandfather would have been proud of the boys # but maybe less so about the team they were playing for. #My grandpa and Jimmy were staunch Furnace men, and there was always this Furnace Inveraray rivalry,# Scott explained.#He always said to me never to join Inveraray, and after he died, my gran carried it on.#When I was  or  I ended up playing for Inveraray, but he was dyed-in-the-wool Furnace through and through. He would be turning in his grave..!#He added: #It#s great to have these photos, and I have sent a lot of them to the Shinty Memories Facebook page, which uses memories to help folk living with issues such as dementia and isolation.#Hopefully people will enjoy seeing them.#

title: crinan canal prepares for phased re opening
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThe Crinan Canal, dubbed #Scotland#s most beautul shortcut# is preparing to re-open to navigation from July .Scottish Canals this week updated interested parties on plans for its waterways network as coronavirus lockdown continues to ease.In a statement, Scottish Canals said: #Since we last wrote to you, the First Minister announced phase two of the easing of lockdown restrictions on Thursday June , and so we wanted to update you on Scottish Canals# ongoing response to COVID- in light of this.#Phase two will see an increase in the volume of outdoor work being carried out by our operational team in areas such as vegetation management, weed-cutting, litter-picking and channel clearance to prepare the canals for navigation.#Our offices, visitor centres, indoor cafes, holiday accommodation, and locks and bridges remain closed until phase three, with the majority of our staff continuing to work from home.#During phase one we welcomed back leisure boaters living within five miles of their mooring and residential boaters to use the canals for local boating. However, there are still numerous restrictions in place, including no operation of locks and bridges, limited services and limited staff available on the ground. This remains the position.#We are, however, pleased to let you know that Scottish Canals is planning to re-open canals to navigation in line with the announcement that Scotland’s tourism sector is preparing to reopen during phase three of the Scottish Government route map on July . Subject to the confirmation of phase three from that date, the canals will open to navigation as follows:While boats will be able to transit the canals, the operating hours and days still have to be confirmed#When the canals were closed to navigation at the beginning of lockdown, mooring customers received three months# navigation licence free of charge to June .Scottish Canals added: #We have decided to extend the concession to cover July, with mooring customers getting a credit note issued to their account next month in addition to April, May and June.#A deferment of boat safety certicates has also been further extended until September.With health and safety in mind, Scottish Canals will adopt strict social distancing, segregation and hygiene measures to minimise the risk of transmitting Covid- for the foreseeable future, including cough screens at transaction points, queue management and clear signage to remind people of the importance of physical distancing and good hand and cough hygiene.

title: letters to the editor july 3 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Communities on the A are blighted by the noise of bikers, many with illegal exhausts.Inveraray is the gathering point for motorcyclists and on a recent Saturday during lockdown around  were gathered, not two metre social distancing, and failing to adhere to the maximum eight in a group guidance.This has become the norm throughout the summer, and it seems lockdown guidance does not apply to bikers as they have been a constant feature on the roads, even in phase one.The unofficial Argyll TT goes past our homes most weekends over the spring and summer months.I have a bike licence and understand the feeling of freedom, but three-figure speeds past residential entrances, many of them hidden, is completely unacceptable.As a resident you begin to dread the weekend and sunny days. The noise is constant and intrusive for  –  hours in a day, the decibel level in excess of  dB where sounds above  dB are harmful to hearing.This is a serious issue for residents who cannot open their doors and windows, cannot use their gardens, pets are terried, it is often impossible to have a conversation, or a phone call. The noise from hundreds of bikes is explosive and destructive.The speeds are terrying, they travel in intimidating packs, the noise is threatening and the bikers have no respect for the communities they are speeding through. They pass multiple residential entrances with limited sight lines with no care for risk. The offensive noise seems to come from two actions modying motorbike exhausts and extreme acceleration in legal bikes.If a car made a similar noise, spewed out the same polluting omissions, or did the same ridiculous speeds they would be pulled over by the police, but bikers appear above the law.As technology reduces the noise pollution of cars, planes and other forms of transport, it seems motorbikes are exempt. Bikers claim #loud pipes save lives# but is safety really the motivation for deliberately creating excessive noise Noise counts as a statutory nuisance it either unreasaonably and substantially interferes with the user or enjoyment of a home or other premises or is likely to injure health.The problem on A is known to all the statutory agencies, but nothing is done.If this is a national problem, what action needs to be taken Concerned Loch Fyne-side resident Sir,I am not qualied to judge economic competence, but considering the party he represents, I think that Councillor Redman might find it advisable to be wary of the phrase #colossal mismanagement# .For my part, I would consider a degree of incompetence to be preferable to the great damage caused over the last decade to  per cent of the UK’s people, as well as to its institutions and its reputation by the cruel, self-serving, xenophobic, elitist, dishonestregime currently in Westminster.Name supplied, LochgilpheadSir,Our charity#s support for blind and partially sighted people affected by the coronavirus lockdown has received a £, boost from the Scottish Government#s Wellbeing Fund.With this extra funding we will be able to support an additional  people and respond to the increased demand for more in-depth, one-to-one emotional support.The practical and psychological effects of losing your sight can have a signicant impact on people’s well-being, and this current situation has exacerbated the anxiety and isolation felt by many.Access to essential services such as food and medicines is more dficult as is social distancing, vital information on staying safe isn#t always in accessible formats, and many of our older members aren#t always confident about using new technology to stay in touch with others.Everyone accessing RNIB#s confidential counselling service will receive eight weekly sessions with an accredited counsellor, delivered via telephone and online, with each session normally lasting an hour.The funding will enable us to reduce the waiting list for emergency mental health sessions and also let existing clients access additional sessions.The RNIB helpline is available on   .James Adams, RNIB Scotland directorSir,Every pub across Scotland should be allowed to stock and sell beer from local independent brewers, to help them recover post-lockdown.CAMRA, the Campaign for Real Ale has launched the #Cheers for Choice# campaign.The campaign wants these arrangements to be relaxed, and MSPs are also being urged to support the Tied Pubs Bill being put forward in the Scottish Parliament by Labour MSP Neil Bibby. The legislation would give tied pub tenants protections in law, including a right to be able to sell guest beers in their pubs.Allowing small and independent brewers to sell into all pubs will also improve consumer choice and allow pub-goers to support local brewing businesses.It also makes business sense, with  per cent of pub-goers saying they would be less likely to go back to a pubit doesn’t have a range of brews from small and independent producers.Sarah Crawford, CAMRA Director for Scotland, Kirkcaldy

title: could a two way conversation transform scotlands health
